element_texts.text: Completed

Physician & Surgeon
Joseph William Zeh B.S., M.D.
4642 N 46th Ave
Chicago, ILL 

Oct 8, 1914

Dearest Mum
So glad to get both your letters. I have joined the "I Will" club went yesterday to one of their "Round Table" meetings held at the home of one of the members a Mrs. Swan, who lived one Wash. Blvd. I wasn't intending to go if I could get out of it, as it was my gym day, but Mrs. Allen called up as she said she would, in the morning and seemed to think it was all settled that I was going, so I went. She was to call for me but she phoned later that she had to go down town on an errand and wanted to know if I couldn't go alone I said yes, so started as soon as my bread was out of the
Completed

oven- about 1:15. Met Mrs. Coney, the club president, accidentally at corner of 40th and Montrose so had her company in the long ride. She is a very pleasant lady and a great friend of Mrs. Allen's. I was glad afterwards that I went for  I had a very pleasant time and awfully good eats. Mrs. Swan occupies a swell apt. on the boulevard. It is very tastefully furnished and very home like. She is a large woman, German I think, and a most excellent cook. She served ice cream, cake and coffee. I didn't take any of the latter but the cake was simply fine. I'm going to get the recipe from her next time I see her. It was a sort of light yellow sponge cake, beautifully made. she had very pretty dishes and served her cake from long handled artistic baskets. Very classy. I think it is quite helpful to go around to other people's houses and learn how to do things nicely.
Completed

Physician & Surgeon
Joseph William Zeh B.S., M.D.
4642 N 46th Ave
Their program consisted of disscussion of current events, then a paper on the geography of Mexico, read by one of the ladies, then discussion of the subject and general conversation. Mrs. Greir told some interesting things that had happened to her when she was in Mexico. They have arranged to have Zona Gale read one of her unpublished village stories at the LaSalle Hotel next Tuesday evening. I got two tickets for myself and Max. I think we will enjoy it very much. Wish you could go too. I think this club will be the means of giving me a good deal of social life, and will help to keep me abreast of the times. 
So glad you are enjoying your visit. Hope the weather will continue to be pleasant all this month. It is lovely here, too.
Completed

I expect to pick out my dress goods tomorrow or next day. Miss Ross said she would go with me and help me to select it.
Mr. Cole paid the September rent some time ago. I think it was about the 20th but am not sure. I can find out the exact date from Max if you would like it.
Have just called up Mrs. Coal, but no one answered. Perhaps she was out for a walk. I will call again later on and see how she is. 
My nasturtiums are still blooming nicely and the pansies are doing well. Max and I are planning to go out to Glen Ellyn Sunday and spend the day if the weather is pleasant. Mummie, how do you fix barley for breakfast food? How much do you use and how long does it have to cook?
Ever so much love,
Katharine
Completed

Physician & Surgeon
Joseph William Zeh B.S., M.D.
4642 N 46th Ave
Oct 10,1914
Precious Marder:
Am going down town this morning to meet Miss Ross and pick out my dress goods. I expect to have two dresses for this winter, both of them quite swell, if possible, as my blue suit is good enough for ordinary wear. 
Made some sugar cookies a couple of days ago which turned out very well but there is still room for improvement  Went yesterday to a meeting of the socialist women of the 27th ward. Mrs. Kennedy was the only one present whom I had met before except one. She has a long German name which I can't remember. I saw her one day going up and down the street putting papers in the mail boxes so I knew she must be a socialist. The paper
Completed

she was distributing was the 27th ward Optimist. I went out and spoke to her, introducing myself and asked her if the women of this ward ever held meetings. She told me of this one so I went. The house was on Kilborn ave. on the other side of the tracks. Most of the women present were German or at least, I think all but three or four spoke with an accent. 
The I Will Club is to have a progressive Auto Luncheon, for 35¢ you get a 3 course luncheon served at 3 different homes with auto rides between the various residences. Mrs. Beers, Mrs. Sumner and Mrs. Greer are the hostesses. This occurs next Thursday. I think I will go. Wish you could come along. Mrs. Slagle and other members will furnish the autos.
Nellie Zay sent me her dues book and P.O.order to pay her dues so I must go to the county office before doing my shopping. I suppose Max will collect the Oct. rent today. Shall I send it to you?
With lots of love, Katharine
Completed

letterhead with photograph
PHYSICIAN & SURGEON  Joseph William Zeh, B.S., M.D.  4642 N 46TH AVE.  CHICAGO, ILL.
Oct. 12, 1914
Ducky Marder  
Went to town Saturday and picked out my dress goods. Got it at Mandel's in the subway. Am enclosing samples. The green serge was $1.00 per yard and the plaid was 75¢   crossed out: The Both pieces together cost $4.50. The lining was 30¢, but that will not show, of course, it is to be used for the upper part of the lower skirt and will be hidden by the tunic. The tunic is to be of the green while the girdle, collar, cuffs and lower skirt will be of the plaid.
Miss Ross expects to come tomorrow to make it for me.
Did not do my washing today as my monthlies made their appearance yesterday. The weather is very cloudy, anyway, not at all good for drying clothes.
Completed

I haven't heard from Elaine yet so don't know whether they are still planning to come to Chicago next month or not. Yesterday was beautiful and sunshiny so Max and I took a long walk down past the river to the little park on Montrose. Saw some semiprofessionals playing tennis and watched the kids in their playground and outdoor gym.
John Bunny is coming to the Auditorium to play in a musical comedy called Bunny in Funnyland. Perhaps we will go to see him. Did you notice the big ad booming Glen Ellyn in last Sunday's Tribune? Max said he would buy one of those lots if he had the money. They are certainly very desirable if your house is equipped with a good heating apparatus for winter and screened in porches for summer. I wonder if the town sewage still empties into the lake. Seems to me they are piping it to the Desplaines river. 
Enjoy yourself, Mummie, and eat lots of good stuff, especially butter and milk that you can't have in Florida. How is Grandma? Much love, Katharine.

Written in left margin   Excuse stingy samples can send others after dress is cut out.
Completed

Physician & Surgeon
Joseph William Zeh B.S., M.D.
4642 N 46th Ave
Chicago, ILL
Oct 16, 1914
Ducky Marder

 Have received both your very entertaining letters. The drawing of you was hardly a speaking likeness but I could tell who

it was meant to be.It doesn't do you justice but it is better by far than the average person could do.

 The lady who drew it made your neck look as though you had an attack of the mumps. I will send it on to Grandma.
 Enjoyed very much your narration of the argument at the church over the vulgar poem. One could write a good many stories that

would be about the New York villagers.

 Miss Ross came Tuesday and stayed until Thursday morning. During that time she made my green dress. It is awfully
Completed

pretty and very stylish looking and is very becoming. Max likes it so you may know from that that it is O.K. in every
particular. I helped on it quite a bit so got it done in time to wear it to the progressive auto luncheon. The weather

has been very rainy and cloudy every day this week except Sunday so I didn't know whether to go Thursday or not.

Called Mrs. Greer to find out the plans and she said that they could have it as planned.  I then notified Mrs. Wilson
who has decided to accompany me and I got into my dress, got my brown coat our of the tar bag and "put same on."
The first house that we went to was Mrs. Beers' over on Greenwood Ave. and 61st so we road over on the R. 1 car.
Found lots of ladies assembled in the halls and parlor waiting for the first tableful of ladies to get through. Saw lots
of people I knew and introduced them to Mrs. Wilson. After about half hour's wait we sat down to the first course.
It consisted of stewed celery, baked potatoes, that is potato au gratin, I think it is termed,
Completed

Physician & Surgeon
Joseph William Zeh B.S., M.D.
4642 N 46th Ave
Chicago, ILL
cold meat, deviled eggs, bread & butter, chili sauce, and pickled peaches.
When this was consumed we went down stairs, got into Mrs. Slagle's auto, and
rode over to Mrs. summer's house, 4242 St. Lawrence Ave. We had a very pleasant
ride through the park. Carlton Slagle drove the car and showed a good deal of skill
that might well be envied by an older and more experienced driver.

 Arrived at Mrs. Summer's we sat down to a salad composed of lettuce, nuts, and

several ingredients which I couldn't determine - and cheese crackers. After this was
eaten we repaired to the Greer's in Mrs. Greer Jr.'s auto. Here we partook of homemade
ice cream and cake and cookies.

 Everything was very good especially the ice cream. I wanted more but was, of course, too

polite to ask for it.
Completed

Saw Dr. Greer and met lots of the club members whom I hadn't seen before. Nearly every member
of the club turned out for this event and I guess it was quite a success financially as well as every
other way.

 Mrs. Wilson enjoyed herself very much and so did I. Got home in time to get supper. I want to get

the goods for my other dress soon as I need something to wear to dances and "such like." She is still
pondering the matter of the typewriter.
Completed

Joseph William Zeh, B.S., M.D.
Physician & Surgeon
4642 46th Ave.
Chicago ILL.
Mr Cole has not yet paid the Oct. rent but guess it will be forthcoming soon. Papa came up to the office a few days ago and Max invited him out to next
Sunday's dinner.

 Mummie, I wouldn't think of letting you pay our dues in the S.P.  If we aren't able to pay them ourselves, I guess we are not good enough to be socialists.
 Pusscat has developed a unique fondness for tomato soup and cocoa. What to do with said cat?
 I almost forgot to tell you about Zona Gale's lecture. Miss Ross decided that she wanted to go too so in order to keep her company we persuaded 

Doc to come (Doc is the goat). I was a little disappointed, not in Miss Gale, but in her story and lecture. Of course, it was interesting but not intensely so
and not so good but that I have ambitions to do better
Completed

than that myself some day. It was all old stuff to a socialist. Of course, the progressives in the audience were very much pleased because I suppose
the thought in her story was new to them. I was glad I went though, just to see Miss Gale herself as she is quite a famous writer.

 What kind of little red berry is that that you sent me. It is very pretty, whatever it is.
 The only objection to the I will club is that all the other members are so much older than myself. However, I don't expect to remain a member longer than

for just this winter. When I get out to Glen Ellyn I can probably join a club of people my own age.

 I will call up Leonora and have Mrs. Felt and perhaps L., take lunch with me. I reminded Max today to get films for your camera. Hope he will not forget.

last you through the winter.     Lots of love,     Katharine

P.S.  Am forwarding you a letter from  Helen. She hasn't written me. I wrote last.

We are getting on very nicely together. Very chummy and amiable. Glad you are having lots of nice farm stuff to eat. Get good and fat so you will have enough to
Completed

If not delivered in five days return to 
Dr. Joseph William Zeh
4642 North 46th Ave.
Chicago, ILL.
10-21-14
Mrs. May Walden
Jordanville
N.Y.
Route 1
c/o Mrs. John D. Shaul
Completed

Joseph William Zeh, B.S., M.D.
Physician & Surgeon
4642 North 46th Ave.
Chicago, ILL.

 Oct 21, 1914

Fweet Mudder:

 This is a lovely day, blue sky, no clouds, thermometer 80. I wonder how long this fine weather will last. I am going over to the gym this afternoon

Have just finished my cleaning and will bake a cake then this letter is finished. I did a big washing Monday, but didn't get very tired, and on Saturday after scrubbing
my floor, I hardly felt fatigued. I think I must be getting more muscle. Yesterday morning Miss Ross called up and invited me to come over to the Lewis's for lunch
and bring my blue skirt so that she could alter it for me. I accepted gladly and went as soon as my ironing was done. We had a nice lunch of baked po-
Completed

tatoes, chipped beef in cream sauce, bran biscuit, applesauce and doughnuts. After lunch Miss Ross fixed my skirt. She took out the inner belt, put a piece in
to make it longer, cut off the top of the skirt to about an inch in depth, sewed the inner belt on again and it was as good as new and fits very nicely. The Lewis's
house is very stately and old fashioned, isn't it? The side porch is the pleasantest part of it. I met both the Misses Lewis but not the mother. They were very
cordial and I enjoyed talking to them. When it was almost time for me to go, Rachel Blake's husband, Mr. Mahoney, came in to see Mr. Blake; he was out,
however so mr. M. didn't stay long. he is very much tanned, from the Mexican sun, I suppose. Mr. Blake went out shortly after I arrived, so I didn't get to see
him. Miss Ross showed me his room. My! hasn't he piles of books? Almost as big a collection as Clarence Darrow.
Completed

Joseph William Zeh, B.S., M.D.
Physician & Surgeon
4642 North 46th Ave.
Chicago, ILL.

  I began to have a headache when I left and it increased in ferocity during my ride home, accompanied by "sea sickness."  I didn't feel well enough to finish

getting supper but sat about waiting to vomit. When Doc came he gave me some Hunyadi Janos in a glass of warm water which I immediately vomited up along with 
my lunch, the most conspicuous ingredient being the chipped beef. It must have been canned and somewhat tainted or it wouldn't have made me sick. I was all right
after that and my headache disappeared.

 Max mailed the films a couple days ago. Hope they will get their soon. I think I will get a camera or petition Max and Doc to give me
Completed

one for Christmas. When the weather is fine like this it seems a shame not to take pictures. The cat is quite a poser. I could practice on him. The tomato vines
are still bearing and the nasturtiums are still blooming. I gathered a lovely big bunch today.   Papa came out Sunday and seemed to enjoy his visit. He talked mostly
about the war. Thinks Germany will be defeated in the end but that the struggle will continue for a year more, anyway.

 After dinner we walked down Alston Ave. to Irving Pk. Blvd. where Papa took a car downtown to the chess & checker club and Doc, Max and I went to a dime show. 

After the show, we walked home, making excellent time, as it was getting chilly.

  I must write to Grandma right away. Haven't heard from Helen yet. Guess she is mad because I didn't write her on her birthday. I was too busy to write to anyone that day.

She owes me a letter, anyway. Wish I could see you, Mummie, and have a good chat.

   Heaps of love,    Tairn.
Completed

Joseph William Zeh, B.S., M.D.
Physician & Surgeon
4642 N. 46th Ave.
Chicago, ILL.

  Oct. 24, 1914

Precious Marder:

 To say I was surprised to read Helen's card to you, would be putting it mildly. speaking of thunderbolts, that certainly was one. I can't understand what induced her

to write that way. She has known you a good deal longer than she has known Genasine Hess, and must know you well enough to be sure that you would not say
anything to hurt her. She must realize that G. Hess is merely a scandal-monger just from her repeating and enlarging upon what you said to her. Still, as you said, 
it is something of a relief to be rid of the bunch. she hasn't answered my letter yet and I doubt she ever will.
Completed

If I ever write her again I will act as though I knew nothing of the card she wrote you.

 Had a fine swim yesterday at the Field House. swam the length of the tank, ending in the deep water. One of the girls walked along beside me on

the platform, holding a long pole out over the water for me to grab hold of if I got tired, but I didn't need it. About a week ago I met a young girl by the name of
Gladys Shroeder in the gym class. She is about my age and we took to one another immediately. I met her yesterday and we went in swimming together and we
are planning to go in again next Wed. morning and have gym in the afternoon. Between periods we will play tennis if the weather permits and eat our lunch in
the park. I'm so glad to have found a girl at last, to play tennis with
Completed

Joseph William Zeh, B.S., M.D.
Physician & Surgeon
4642 N. 46th Ave.
Chicago, ILL.
although it is near the end of the season. This girl is a graduate of the Carl Schurtz High School and made a specialty of music afterwards. She now gives piano lessons,
more for pocket money than to actually earn her living, I think, as she lives at home and her people are fairly well-to-do. They have a Overland auto and she has invited
me to go out in it sometime: Isn't that nice?

 We are planning to go to the concert at the Art Institute tomorrow. I was much interested in your visit to Cooperstown. Sorry you had to buy films there to use.

Max has been waiting to have the others developed in order to send them all together, but the company
Completed

that does the work spent an unusually long time on them and then, after all, only two were good. I didn't see them but Max said they were both very pretty pictures.

 The weather has been so warm that according to an item in the Day Book, the roses and lilacs are budding and coming out, the former in Jackson Pk., the latter in

Oak Park.

 Mummie, what no. of thread was it that you used to make my crocheted collar? I have some of the coarse crochet cotton, no. 3, but I'm afraid that won't do.
 Max has been going up every day lately to get the Oct. rent from Mr. Cole, but so far has been unsuccessful. When he gets it, shall he send it to you?
     Lots of love,
      Katharine.
Completed

J.W. Zeh, B.S., M.D.
Physician and Surgeon
4642 N. 46th Avenue
Chicago

 Oct 31, 1914.

Precious Mum:

It is warm and balmy again. The sun shone beautifully all day and the fire in the furnace was wholly unnecessary.
  The letter I wrote Patty was returned today all marked up by the postal authorities who evidently tried in vain to

find her. I put on the envelope c/o Selig Polyscope Co. besides her address at the Panama Apts. but neither
place was the right one. I wonder where to she has tone. perhaps she has got married and quit her work and
assumed her husband's name, so even if she were still in Los Angeles I would find it difficult to locate her.
Perhaps I shall hear from her soon. At the club meeting the other day Mrs. Greer said that Mrs. Felt is here in
town and is staying alternately with Leonora and Mrs. Thompson. Will try to get in touch with her.

 The last club meeting was way over on
Completed

the south side, 71st and Prairie, at the home of a Mrs. Mills. There was a civics program including speeches by Miss Vittum, progressive candidate for county
commissioner, Jailer Whitman  of the Bridewell, and Rev. Moore of Boston. The latter's speech didn't amount to much. Miss Vittum's was the best. She has
spent a deal of time investigating conditions in the Chicago police stations and in fact in those of a number of other places, including European cities like
Berlin, Vienna, Budapest, etc. and she says that the Chicago stations are the worse of the lot as to sanitation. she says women prisoners in most of the stations
have no privacy whatever and cannot take off any clothing all during their lockup time. Their cells are usually situated at the back of the station and as the only means of
carrying away the filth and waste matter
Completed

Joseph William Zeh, B.S., M.D.
Physician & Surgeon
4642 N. 46th Ave.
Chicago, ILL.
from all the prisoners by means of a sort of open gutter or groove in the cement floor, - by the time it flows to the back of the station where the women are located
the stench is almost intolerable. She also told of the sleeping arrangements among the policemen where the day and night squads are obliged to take turns
sleeping in the same beds. she said one case she knew of was of an ordinary policeman who was obliged to strip off all his clothing in the basement of his home
and don other garments before his wife would let him come upstairs - such was the quantity of vermin that he carried home from the station house beds.
Completed

She told of other things too, - how policemen are forced to graft in order to keep their jobs - how they were obliged to favor the ward bosses if they didn't
want to be moved from one side of the city to another - etc.  Jailer Whitman spoke mostly on the informed methods of dealing with prisoners, the medical
examinations made which showed diseased minds and bodies which prompt them to commit crime. he says that 50 per cent of all the people sent him as
prisoners are suffering from some disease or are in need of some severe surgical operation. A great number of complex operations are obliged to be performed
every week at the Detention home.

 I will see if I can get your money from Kennedy. We spent a pleasant evening at cards yesterday at Mrs. Andrews' daughter's house. Her husband is an artist.

He draws pictures for many of the magazines such as Life, Judge, Everybody's, etc. he showed us a number of them and they are really very fine. His name
is Herndon.
Completed

Joseph William Zeh, B.S., M.D.
Physician & Surgeon
4642 N. 46th Ave.
Chicago, ILL.
They have two little children, a boy of 4 and a girl nearly 2. They are very pleasant people and intellectually superior to the Wilsons.

 I am embroidering a crash pillow top for my pine needle (or rather balsam) cushion. I think it will be very pretty when it ids done.

It is a conventional design to be worked in green, yellow and brown. Got the whole thing, silk and all, for a quarter at Anderson's. Pretty good,
I thought.   I haven't heard from Helen yet, Don't suppose I will. I'm glad you heard from her father. I shall be glad to have him in for dinner
sometime. I enjoy hearing him talk and, besides, he has entertained us a good many times.

 Papa said that grandpa is quite well
Completed

again. He can see enough to play golf, but not to read. He has several people come in and read to him, however, so it isn't as bad as we thought. If he comes to Chicago, will have him come out to visit me.

 Yes, I certainly shall not be friendly with Helen until she apologizes to you. I sometimes think she must be a little insane, on some subjects, at least.
 The club girls are coming out to see me a week from tomorrow. They are all getting on amiably together once more and they meet every two weeks instead of every week. Thank you very much for the photos of Darts Camp and the lake. Have pasted them into my diary. Ethel enclosed in her letter a couple of pictures that were taken at Lake Zurich this summer when I was there. I have pasted them in too. I don't want you to spend so much money on my Christmas present Mummie - but howsomever, will see how things are going when the time comes.    Heaps of love,      Katharine.
Completed

J.W. Zeh, B.S., M.D.
Physician and Surgeon
4642 N. 46th Avenue
Chicago

 Nov. 5, 1914

Precious Mum.

 I suppose you are in New York City now. My!  It seems difficult to imagine you there. One usually thinks of New York as a sort of awe inspiring, far-away place,

difficult to reach, and hard to get about in, once there. I suppose, though, it is a good deal like Chicago, only cleaner. Am waiting eagerly your description of it.
How nice that you are to be with Verne Sheridan. Is she working now and is she well?  Give her my love.

 I mailed the switch yesterday as you requested. Hope Cousin Cora can make use of it. Thank you for the photo. I will write Cousin Libbie and thank her. You look

rather stiff and uncomfortable in the picture. It doesn't do you justice at all and I suppose it is the same with Libbie and Nellie. Is Nellie of those relatives that
I find it hard
Completed

to remember relationships, having never seen any of them.  I shall have to diagram them as the school histories do the royal houses of Europe.  thus

                                            Aunt    Margaret
                                           |                       |
                                     ___________   ________
                                     Cousin Cora    C. Libbie
                                            |                      |
                                     ___________    ________
                                      Myrtle etc.      {C. Nellie (by marriage)
                                                            {C. Ray
                                                                   |
                                                             _________
                                                               Darwin

On looking at one of your other letters I find that Cousin Nellie is Ray's wife and mother of Darwin. Is it Myrtle who is going south with you?

 I bet grandma will be tickled to death to have you back again. I enclose a letter that Nellie Zay wrote to Max. It gives a good deal of news about

herself and will give you an idea of what she is doing.   

   The nuts you sent Max were indeed a welcome gift. You couldn't have sent anything that he would 

have liked better. He takes a handful every hour or so when he is at home and has a regular eat-fest. It must be lovely to live
Completed

J. W. Zeh, B.S., M.D.
Physician & Surgeon
4642 N. 46th Ave.
Chicago, ILL.
where you can go out and gather nuts instead of buying them.

 I hope you will be able to get in touch with Ada May Krecker while you are in New York.   
 Mrs. Wilson's father in law who was running for County Commissioner

was not elected much to the chagrin of the whole Wilson family. The town has gone almost entirely democratic, according to the incomplete returns that I have
seen thus far. Probably the N.Y. papers will give accounts of the election.

 Nellie Zay sent a fine big chicken for Max's birthday dinner and I made him a cake, cocoanut, like the one I made for you, so you see he had plenty to eat. He had

about 50 nuts for his second course. Doc was obliged to lie down after the meal. I gave Max a new shirt and a pair of cuff buttons for his birthday.

 Puss cat has gained a good deal since you left. he now weighs 9 pounds.
Completed

Pretty good for a cat only 9 months old, isn't it? He is so tall that he can easily put his forepaws on one of the dining-room window sills, when standing on his
hind legs.

 Max and I went over to Norine Crawford's last Sunday and visited with her. The park looks much the same except that they have a fountain, or rather, just a

large spray of water shooting up in the middle of the small pond just north of the lagoon. Norine said that it was to be made into a swimming pool for children
next summer. On our way over to the L someone came up behind and walked in between us and turning we beheld - Ritterscomp! He is looking well and has
been working all summer on a sort of dredging job. Guess he has cut out drinking for he looks quite civilized. He chatted with us a few minutes and then went
off toward Cottagegrove.

 Doc announced last night that he had purchased tickets for "While the city sleeps" at the Auditorium for Friday night. It is a play being given for the policemen's

benefit ass'n.     Write soon and tell me all about Noo Yawk.      Lots of love,    Katharine.
Completed

J. W. Zeh, B.S., M.D.
Physician & Surgeon
4642 N. 46th Ave.
Chicago
Nov 23, 1914
Precious Mudder & Grandma:

 Was very glad to get your letter telling of your safe arrival  My! What a fine trip you had didn't you? So glad you could see the ocean and ride on it and what a fine thing that you weren't seasick.   We had a pleasant time at the dance last Wednesday, though there was rather a small crowd. The Wilsons played cards and we danced. Neither Mr. nor Mrs. W. can dance well. Met several pleasant people. I wore my new dress and it looked very pretty. wish you could see it. I feel that I have plenty of dresses now. The only thing I need is a hat. Had a nice visit from Margaret Kelly. Talked over old times at Hyde Park. she is still working though not in the same place.
 Saturday evening we took dinner with
Completed

Papa at King's restaurant and went to see the war pictures at the Studebaker. They are movies taken by Edwin F. Weigle of the Tribune photography staff. He has just brought them back from Belgium where he took war scenes, people digging in the ruins of their homes, etc.

_ I am finishing this letter early Tuesday morning as Mrs. Felt came at this juncture. The war pictures were well worth seeing. Perhaps your theater in Avon Park will contact for the film. Tell the manager he can get one by writing the International Motion Picture Co., Room 508, 7 So. Dearborn St. Chicago.
 Sunday morning Max went down to the office to get out some letters and in the afternoon I et him at the Art Institute and we heard the concert. Am enclosing program. Instead of the 5th number which the leader had left at home, as he told the audience, they played selections from Mignon. We both enjoyed it very much. Saw some beautiful pictures, too.
 I guess I told you that I had invited Mrs. Felt over to supper. Had a very nice visit.
Completed

J. W. Zeh, B.S., M.D.
Physician & Surgeon
4642 N. 46th Ave.
Chicago
with her. She said so many funny things, just as she always does. wish you could have been here to listen to her. She is debating whether or not to have another operation as
the first did no good. she has a woman doctor this time, a specialist on female diseases, who is giving her treatment in the shape of medicines and exercises. she says (the doctor) that if this does not remedy the trouble she would advise an operation. It seems that Mrs. Felt's uterus is misplaced, upside down, in fact, and she flows a great deal of the time. She says she is anemic and I suppose she is, but you could never tell it from her face as she had it very skillfully made up.  If she decides not to have the operation she expects to go back to Omaha next Sunday or Monday. After supper we went to see the Million Dollar Mystery. Mrs. Felt wanted to see if she could help me towards a solution of the problem.
I have one solution outlined in my mind but can't tell yet whether it is a reasonable one. The story part in the
Completed

Tribune is finished but we haven't seen all the pictures yet.

 It is raining today and the weather is gloomy. Had a lovely day yesterday for my washing.
 Just got a letter from Nellie Zay saying that she is staying in Muskegon part of the time tying to keep warm - that it got so cold on the farm she couldn't stand it.
  Mummie, have you ever read any of Bret Harte's stories. I came across a volume of them in the library and am enjoying them very much. I see we have one of her books "A Ward of the Golden Gate" here in the bookcase. Think I will read in when I have finished this one.
 Yes, you sent me some of the farm pictures. Believe I returned the picture of Libbie, Nellie and yourself a few days ago. let me know whether you receive it.   Have invited Papa to take dinner with us Thanksgiving. Guess we will have chicken instead of turkey. Hope you have a nice dinner and spend a pleasant day.
   Heaps of love      Katharine.
Completed

J. W. Zeh, B.S., M.D.
Physician & Surgeon
4642 N. 46th Ave.
Chicago
Nov 28, 1914
Ducky Marder.

 Thank you very much for the photos. Am returning some of which I have duplicates that you sent me from New York. Much pleased with description of your berth and its accoutrements. (is that the way to spell it?)  It must have been quite an exciting trip. Too bad so many of the passengers were sick. Am glad you were not.
 Cole paid the Nov. rent a few days ago. We received a bill from Randall for $4.50 for fixing the roof so paid him out of the rent. I think Max has forwarded the latter to you.
 Had a quiet day Thanksgiving. Had chicken (stewed_, cranberry sauce, mashed potatoes, baking powder biscuit, figs, nuts, candy, celery, and pumpkin pie. I made the pie after your recipe and it was a great success. Made another one yesterday so as to use
Completed

up the can of pumpkin that I got. Went to a meeting of the I will club yesterday at 4242 St. Lawrence Ave. Don't think I will go often when the meeting place is so far away. I dread the car ride in those stuffy cars.  I nearly always get sick to my stomach when I ride in them. They are giving a card party tonight at the home of a Mrs. Forbes on West Adams street. Max and I are going and the Wilsons were intending to go but Mr. W. has some lodge doings on hand which will prevent their going.   This is a lovely day. sunny and warm enough to go for a walk bare headed.  When I said "send drawing to Frank" I meant the drawing of you which you sent me from Cooperstown or thereabouts which I forwarded to grandma. she has it now, I suppose.

 Hope the laundry position will be congenial. You won't have to do any of the actual laundry work, will you?
Completed

J. W. Zeh, B.S., M.D.
Physician & Surgeon
4642 N. 46th Ave.
Chicago
The pansies all died as grandma predicted. Am quite disappointed as I was very anxious to have some blooming house plants this winter. I suppose I had not better start others until we get out to Glen Ellyn as we might have trouble moving them.  At the last I will Club meeting I met Mrs. Whittemore, the Glen Ellyn member. She is pleasant and agreeable but rather backward in her ideas regarding problems of the day such as unemployment, charity, etc. she enthused about the Christmas ship but thought the unemployed should be driven out of Chicago and forbidden to reenter. "Such policies I no understand". She belongs to the G.E. Woman's study club. She says they have 60 members. I told her that you were one of the charter members and she was much interested.

 Papa was here to dinner on Thanksgiving Day and after dining, we played Euchre, the game they are to play tonight. I picked it up in no time
Completed

recollecting most of it from the instructions you gave me when we used to play together.

 Do you remember how we used to get out the Encyclopedia Brittanica and fret and stew over cribbage meanwhile pegging "one for his head and two for his heels"?  I have just learned that if you pass the county examination for school teacher and substitute for six months you can receive a certificate to teach. I have a desire to try, anyway. I should love to teach school in Glen Ellyn and since a normal school training isn't absolutely necessary it may be that I can be a school marm after all.  I haven't written Mr. Bowen yet but intend to do so immediately. I was going to have him in for Thanksgiving but it became necessary to invite papa instead so I shall have him in some Sunday.
 Must stop now and mail this before Mrs. Wilson comes down. I agreed to "mind" Muriel this afternoon while her mother is away.   Much love to both,   Katharine.
Completed

J. W. Zeh, B.S., M.D.
Physician & Surgeon
4642 N. 46th Ave.
Chicago

 Dec. 3, 1914

Dearest Mummie

 Have got my washing done and the house partly cleaned so will have a little recreation now in the way of letter-writing. I don't usually wash on Thursday but Monday and Tuesday were rainy and Wednesday wasn't much better.   We had a very nice time at the card party, given by the I Will Club. I think I told you we were planning to attend it. Mrs. Allen won first prize for the ladies and Mr. Slagle got the men's prize. Mrs. A's prize was an oil painting which had been executed by the hostess' mother. The other prize was two books on the geography and points of interest of Pompeii and Venice. I don't believe Mr. Slagle enthused much over them. I know Max didn't.
 Glad you have a new cook stove. No, you didn't send me the miniature souvenir post cards of N.Y. Shall be very glad
Completed

to have them.   I am sending (or about to send, in a few weeks) Grandma a copy of Bamby in book form for Christmas, so you can see how it turns out for yourself.

 Sorry Mr. Hart is going to lose his baby. I should think his accumulation of troubles would be enough to discourage anyone. I think that would be a fine idea for you to start up a laundry.  Am enclosing the names of manufacturers' that you wanted.
 The last time Miss Ross was here I asked her about the typewriting but she said she wanted to wait until she had time to go over her stories again and make some changes

be-fore having them typed. Yes, I have read Damaged Goods but not the other two plays in the volume. I believe I can get it at the library so you won't need to send me your volume. Yes, thank you, Mummie, should be very glad of the union suits. It isn't cold enough to wear them yet but it probably will be soon. I think if you pay for a camera
Completed

J. W. Zeh, B.S., M.D.
Physician & Surgeon
4642 N. 46th Ave.
Chicago
for me you will be doing ample without purchasing tights too. I can easily get those myself. I wouldn't have you send me the union suits but for the fact that I know you cannot use them this winter. So glad you could make use of the opera glasses.

 I will mail you some of the Reviews - all that you missed if I can find them.   I wrote Mr. Bowen and invited him in to take dinner with us next Sunday. I hope he will come. I enjoy talking with him and Max does too. Of course, he is peculiar in some ways like the rest of the Bowens and like the rest of all the folks in the world but that doesn't keep him from being a very pleasant companion for a short time.  I haven't heard from Helen nor from Pattie. I told you didn't I, that the letter I wrote Pattie was returned to me? I should like very much to have her address and to know what she is doing.
Completed

If you start up the laundry yourself have you a store or building of some sort in mind that you could rent for the purpose? How much would you have to pay the darkies?

 Am sending you one of the Advance Laundry price lists so you can t ell what to charge for your work. Max will print you some price lists if you want them.

Never mind sending the cook book unless you have already done so as you gave me the most important recipes when you were here and the ones in the "52 Sunday Dinners" book will do very well.    With lots of love,

                                            Katharine.

Don't tell Grandma about my sending her Bamby.
Completed

J. W. Zeh, B.S., M.D.
Physician & Surgeon
4642 N. 46th Ave.
Chicago

 Dec 8, 1914

Dearest Mum and Grandma. -

 Many thanks for the cookbook which arrives Saturday. Found it waiting for me in the evening when Max and I got home; also found telegram from Geo. B.? (very Bowenesque Method of Communication at half past the 11th hour,) stating that he would be unable to come to dinner Sunday; would come some other time. The message was sent collect so the invitation turned out to be a very profitable one all round.  I wonder what has or will become of Helen.
 Found many recipes in the cookbook that I had forgotten all about and am very glad to have. I expect Max to bring the typewriter home this evening, so shall have an opportunity to copy them more rapidly if I use it.    Municipal dances are now being held at different parts of the city nearly every night. They are proving to be
Completed

J. W. Zeh, B.S., M.D.
Physician & Surgeon
4642 N. 46th Ave.
Chicago
a big success. They charge 15 c a person for admission and the wardrobe is free. They are held at the best halls in the city and according to the newspapers, are very well attended. We haven't gone to one yet, but intend to soon.

 It snowed last night and the ground was all white this morning but it isn't cold, and the snow is melting fast. Got our second lot of coal in last Saturday.   When does your subscription to the Pictorial Review expire? Why don't you write to Peggy Key Scott of the Daughters of the Golden Treasure and try to get some subs? I should think you could get quite a number of your neighbors to subscribe and you would get a quarter on each one beside the presents they give away.
 The knife & scissors arrives with your letter and will have them sharpened Thursday when I go down town. will get the needles, too. I feel quite rich
Completed

with all those stamps you sent.

 Am going to Edison Park this afternoon with Mrs. Wilson. She is going to "speak a piece" at some sort of entertainment. she is allowed to bring one guest and I am to be "it".
Much love to both,      Katharine.
Completed

Dear Mummie and Grandma:

 Just a short note today so you can see my new correspondence cards. Thank you very much, grandma, for your picture.

I have one taken several years ago but an especially glad to have this one. It is a very good likeness.    So glad you are enjoying the Tribune.
Are you the only people in town who get it?  if so, you will
[1914] December
on the side: will pick out your present to me as soon as Cole "comes across". Much obleeg?d? [obliged?]
Completed

soon be authorities so far as news is concerned. Hope the package arrives O.K. 
Did the nail scissors, etc. reach you? Don't remember whether you mentioned them or not 
in your last letter. Got a check for $3.00 through 
Papa from Grandpa for Xmas. 

" brought book of plays by Granville Barker and box candy. Sam & Elaine sent photo album

with photos taken at their place.      Much love      Katharine

Joseph William Zeh, B.S., M.D.
Physician & Surgeon
4642 N. 46th Ave.
Chicago, ILL.

 Jan 29, 1915.

Precious Mudder:

 Got both your letters. Have written Nellie Zay to see if any of her neighbors will take some fruit. Maybe she would buy some herself. Will ask the Wilsons about taking some and anybody else I can find. Went over to see Miss Ross Thursday and brought home on of her manuscripts to write on my machine. She has purchased a little one (forget the name) which is operated differently from the one I am used to and I prefer to use my own. She wants to borrow my typewriter manual, in order to learn the touch system. Wednesday I went swimming and am going again this afternoon. Yesterday attended the meeting of the I Will Club at Mrs. Slagle's house. Mrs. Sanguinet (pronounced Sangvinay) a very pleasant young member of the club invited Max and me over to play cards with them Sat. evening. She lives in the Bldg. which Mrs. Allen

across top and along side:
Jime's picture was in the dramatic section of the next to the last page in the frame of public favor. At the top of the page is the heading
"Right off the Reel".
Completed

owns, over on Winthrop Ave. I was expecting to  go down town today. I had written Margaret Schoenfeld to see if she couldn't meet me downtown, but a letter from her this morning said that she couldn't come today but would meet me a week from Wednesday. 

 I have planned to go down Monday and will get Grandma's ribbon. If I don't get the right kind, send it back & I will exchange it - no trouble at all.  Will get my camera Monday sure Have been planning to do so for some time but something usually turned up to prevent. Have almost learned how to float.
 The French dictionaries of which you speak are not among the books that are unpacked. They must be somewhere among the ones in the basement. If we were not going to move so soon I would unpack them and find them but I think it would be better to wait until we get out to Glen Ellyn. Then I will send them to you as soon as they are unearthed.  Cold is in Chicago but is rather hard to find. He promised to pay up this week but has not so far. Max goes to his office frequently and will probably get him to cough up in the near future.
 Glad you liked the spoon, Grandma. Wanted to have it engraved but was in a hurry to send it, and engraving takes several days, that is, several

continued on side:
days elapse before you can get the article to be engraved. Sorry the movie business is on the bum. No sign of the 10,000 yet

 Lots of love,     Katharine
Completed

Joseph William Zeh, B.S., M.D.
Physician & Surgeon
4642 N. 46th Ave.
Chicago, ILL.

 Feb 2, 1915

Dearest Mummie and Grandma

 Didn't get down town yesterday after all on account of a severe rain which lasted all day, and as I was unwell at the same time, thought I had better not venture out.   Went down today, however, and got my camera, one just like yours and a roll of film for it. Can hardly wait for it to be delivered so I can take some pictures. Hope they will be a success.  Am enclosing the ribbon I got for you, Grandma. If it isn't what you want, send it back and I will be glad to exchange it for you.  Bought myself a very pretty delicate pink crepe de chine waist, $1.95. The color becomes me and I am quite pleased with it.
 I am ripping apart my old blue silk class-night dress and am going to clean it and try making it into a dressing sack.
Completed

I think there will be enough good material in it to make one and I can trim it, partially, at least, with the same ornamental braid that was on the dress. Even if it is not a success it will be good practice for me and I couldn't have worn the dress again as it was.

 I had begun to think I was pregnant again as I went from Nov. 21st to Jan 30th without being unwell but I am sick once more so guess there was nothing doing after all.  I feel very well all the time so I guess the failure to menstruate more frequently is nothing serious.
 The I Will Club is giving a card party  Thursday at the La Salle Hotel and I expect to attend. I understand Mrs. Meder to say that there was to be a municipal dance at Arcadia Thursday evening but on inquiring at the information bureau of the Tribune today, was informed that there was to be none there until next week. So don't know whether we will go to a dance this week or not.   I know that I am going to enjoy my camera immensely and I thank you ever so much for the money to buy it with.
  Lots & lots of love to you both      from Tairn.
Completed

Joseph William Zeh, B.S., M.D.
Physician & Surgeon
4642 N. 46th Ave.
Chicago, ILL.

 Feb 5, 1915

Dearest Mummie:

 You must have been somewhat surprised to receive the ribbon and not the coral silk. I overlooked the request for the silk in grandma's letter, or I most certainly should have sent it last Tuesday with the ribbon. I was downtown yesterday but didn't do any shopping. However, I looked at coral silk at Mandel's and the only thing I could find was taffeta at $1.50 per yard. It was a beautiful piece of goods but I didn't buy it as I thought I had better look around a little more and see if I could get something for a little less - or is that about the price you wanted to pay?  I am going down again Saturday and if I can't find anything else will get that at Mandel's. They had no remnants there   Perhaps I can find some at some
Completed

other store. I attended the I Will Club card party at the LaSalle Hotel yesterday and had a pleasant time. Got a score of 28 (we played euchre) and the score of the lady who got second prize was 30, so you see mine wasn't so bad. The prizes were a pair of silk stockings and a box of handkerchiefs. Mrs. Allen made the latter. The lecture by Mrs. Havelock Ellis on Eugenics was to be held that evening at Orchestra Hall and they arranged that I was to attend with Mrs. Allen as a delegate from the I Will Club.  I took dinner with Mrs. Allen and then after a session at the nickel show, went over to the lecture.  We had seats on the stage in the company of fifty other club women. I didn't enjoy it nearly as much as I had anticipated because it was almost impossible to hear. We just caught a sentence here and there so after all, the n.s. was more enjoyable than the lecture. Everyone else on the platform seemed to experience the same difficulty that we did.

 Dr. Evans of the Tribune, brave in well-
Completed

Joseph William Zeh, B.S., M.D.
Physician & Surgeon
4642 N. 46th Ave.
Chicago, ILL.
pressed evening clothes and glossy shirt front, gave the preceding talk, chiefly concerning Mr. Havelock Ellis, a sort of biography. It was easier to understand him than the others because his voice was stronger, but the subject was nothing to be enthused over.

 My camera was delivered this morning and I have been reading the accompanying booklet on photography. In accordance with their offer I am mailing a request for the magazine Kodakery, which is said to give hints and helps on picture taking.
 I was sorry to hear of Frank Comb's misfortune. Will you please ask Mr. Woodruff what his address is, so that I may write him a note of condolance. I should like very much to get in touch with him again as he was a very good friend of mine and one whose acquaintance I should like to keep up.
Completed

Mrs. Hart did my washing and scrubbed the kitchen floor yesterday morning and excepting a few handkerchiefs, she got the clothes nice and clean. It was over two weeks since the washing had been done and she was thorough with everything promptly at twelve, so I think she did pretty well.

 Mrs. Swan of the I Will Club is giving a valentine party for the ladies a week from tomorrow afternoon. Tomorrow I am to attend the convention of the Middle Western Land Association as delegate from the club together with a young girl by the name of Mrs. Foster, also a member. I'm getting to be quite a gadabout don't you think? If one wanted to go to all of the club doings and be a delegate to everything that comes up, she could be on the go all the time.
 It is snowing and thawing at the same time and the result is a fine mess of slush and pools of water.
 Do you remember the recipe for Yorkshire pudding that we used to have with roast beef? Should like very much to have it if you do.
     Lots of love to both,    Katharine
Completed

4641 N. Kenton Ave.
May 10, 1915.
Dearest Mummie:

All stationery except this is packed so this letter will have to be brief. Max and I were out to Glen Ellyn Fri. & Sat. Varnished the two front room floors, and the dining room & bedroom floors, also the hallway in the addition.  Painted the northroom floor Mahogany brown, also bathroom floor, hallway and stairs. Varnished the vestibule floor

on side and upside down across bottom:
Mr. Mounsey, the man who was to move us went down on the Lusitania, also his son-in-law too.  Mrs. Wilson's brother married Myrtle Mounsey. Sally M. sent a cable from
Queenstown saying she is safe but destitute.
Completed

Will move Tuesday or Wednesday. Address me at Glen Ellyn right along now. The Wilsons upstairs are going to move to a place in Ravenswood the last of this month. Place was pretty dirty. Cleaned all rooms except kitchen. Am leaving the worst till the last. The floors look very nice now and as soon as the bedroom woodwork is fixed, think it will look very homelike. Am going to white enamel the woodwork in the upstairs bedrooms.    Heaps of love,    Katharine.
Completed

Glen Ellyn, ILL.
May 13, 1915.
Dearest Mummie & Grandma:

 This letter would have been written sooner but I was interrupted in my preparations by the Rev. Moore of the Methodist church who called to see what church I attended. He wasn't as shocked as I expected he would be when I said I didn't go to any and was a socialist & atheist. After his call I told him I could come hear him preach sometime. He is well educated and understands socialism as well as a Methodist preacher could be expected to. I shall introduce him to Dr. Zeh and then stand back & watch the fur fly.
 Well, we are all moved and partly settled. Came out Wednesday at noon. I rode on the truck and enjoyed the
Completed

enjoyed the trip very much. Pusscat's howls could be heard above the roar of the motor and as one of the men aptly observed "they didn't have to toot the horn when he was on on board". I carried him in the wicker satchel that Mrs. Marshall gave you - I guess you know which one I mean.  I held it in my lap all the way and took him out of it, shutting  him into the east room as soon as we got here. He roamed all over the house when I let him out and as soon as he found his favorite rug he was quite contented.

 Max beat both the big rugs as soon as he had connected up the gas stove - then put the two front rooms in order. The varnish had dried nicely, also the paint.  We are going to occupy the north room. Just put up curtains to the west window half an hour ago.  I shall make some plain white curtains for the diamond pane windows.
Completed

The pie plant is growing nicely and I think I shall be able to get several messes from it in a day or two. The asparagus has gone to the diel? and will have to be replanted. The peonies look fine. There are going to be lots of blossoms. The lilies of the valley are blooming. They smell so sweet. Wish you could have some. Guess they will have to be thinned out they are growing so quickly.

 Oh, I mustn't forget to tell you that last night about six o'clock Virginia Kopp came over with a dozen lovely hot rolls that her mother had baked for our supper. Wasn't that just the loveliest thing you ever heard of? I was quite taken aback and hardly knew how to thank her. Just think how different people are here from those in the city. Such neighborliness is unheard of there.
Completed

Virginia and another little girl have been deluging me with flowers. They brought syringa, lilacs, pansies and wild flowers. I feel very happy indeed to be near such nice people.  Must stop now and run over to the store for some potatoes. did I tell you the Wilsons are going to move the 1st of June. Dr. Zeh is going to sleep at 4642 until they go; will have his meals down town.  It's too bad Grandma, that the rheumatism doesn't leave you. I hope you can go up to the mountains if you think that will help you. The change of scene is bound to do you good.      Heaps of love,  Katharine.
Completed

Glen Ellyn, Ill.

May 19, 1915

Precious Mummie & Grandma -

 I am writing from a little office on Main street where Margaret Schoenfeld is keeping shop in the absence of both proprietors John Kempp and Katharine Robertson, respectively undertaker and Shampooist. The town looks much as it always did except that there are a number of new buildings and quite a few autos skip here and there through the highways.    We are quite comfortable at home now. wish you could see the place in its new clothes. The garden is coming
Completed

along nicely. Max planted the corn Sunday and a few more beans. He also mowed the lawn and touched up the yard here and there. Mrs. Kopp continues to be delightfully generous. Is always sending me something. Two days ago it was some lemon cream pie. Yesterday a ginger cake for my lunch. I gave her some pie plant pie and some of the fudge I made yesterday.   Margaret is reading  Brieux's plays which I brought down this morning. She is a deep thinking girl and will be quick to appreciate
Completed

them. I find her a pleasant companion.

 We are planning to get a nice 6x9 rug for our parlor some time this week. Then as soon as my lace curtains are laundered and hung up, the room will look very pretty. I want to get some portires? for the doorway between the parlor and hall and the one leading to the library. Max is going to make some shelves for the books to fit in the southwest corner of the library. They will be handy to the window seat and will make the room look very homey.
Completed

Mrs. Cleaver surprised me yesterday afternoon by ringing the doorbell. She stayed only a few minutes but I enjoyed her little visit very much. She spoke of you a number of times and sent her love to you. I urged her to stay but she said that Mr. C. was waiting for her at the station and that they were only out for a very short time, just to look their place over. She said the last tenants left owing over $300.00.  I hope the Coles wont serve them the same way. I didn't say anything about their treatment of you in the way of prompt (?) pay-
Completed

ments for fear of discouraging her. I don't even know whether she is aware that her present tenants are our old ones. I guess the Griffith place was the only one vacant so they took it. The rent there is $40.00 per month. It will be almost a miracle if she can get all her money out of them. However, it is better to have the place rented and get something for it than to let it stand idle.

 How are you by now, Grandma? I wish you both could visit me this summer and eat some of the lovely cherries that are coming. I wonder if I can't
Completed

arrange to send you some. We are having awfully cold weather. I had to wear my winter coat this morning as I have for the past 4 or 5 days. I hear that most of the Mich. and Wis. fruit was killed by frost. We had a very light one last night but it did no damage.  Took a walk up to the old Hill farm yesterday. It looks just the same as ever. They still cut ice in the little pond in winter.

 It doesn't seem quite natural at home without you, Mummie. Wish I could see you.      Heaps of love      Katharine
Completed

Glen Ellyn, ILL

 May 21, 1915

Dearest Mummie & Grandma:

 Got your letters just as I had mailed one to you. How nice of you, Grandma, to offer to make me some portieres. I shall be delighted to have them and I will rustle around immediately and collect silk things to s end you. Max has a number of old neckties to contribute and Margaret has promised me some things. I shall probably get quite a quantity of silk from my neighbors. I think that I have nothing of my own to send except my old blue silk dress and a few ribbons.
 Max and I are so pleased with our new or rather old home and are enjoying so much fixing it up and arranging and rearranging things.  There are a few more pictures to be unpacked and hung and the lace curtains are still to be laundered and put up, but aside from those

across top;
I am enclosing a handkerchief which belongs to you Mummie.
I found it in the pocket of my old coat after moving.
on side:  Tomorrow is baby's first birthday.
Completed

things we are pretty well settled. I expect to go in town tomorrow to get a rug for the front room and some curtains for the library. We expect to get a new set of dished soon and linoleum for the kitchen. Then we will feel quite elegant. Max is enjoying the garden so much and takes great pride in it and in the yard as well. The latter still looks quite neglected but he hopes to get it in shape before long. I made a lovely strawberry shortcake the other day and gave half of it to Margaret & her grandma. Earlier in the day M. brought me a bowl of chicken noodle soup for my lunch. It had a large piece of chicken in it and was fine. Our exchange of "food gifts" in the neighborhood amuses Max very much.

 I've heard lots of news lately about the people I used to know. Marion Morse is married (last summer) and lives somewhere in Michigan. (No one seems to know just where.

Irene Baethke is
Completed

engaged to Worrel Grimshaw (the people who live in the old Vallette place which has been made into the imposing Mansion with a colonial front.  Harry Clare is married and lives in a house on this street just east of the Episcopal Church. May Lenyard lives just 4 doors east of us with her mother. She is engaged and has been for about 4 years. No sign of her marrying soon.  Agnes Hoadley goes about with an insignificant looking young man named Bick. Don't think she is engaged to him. Hazel Lurkamer broke off her engagement and still works at Wheaton as does Rose Dodge. Corrinne Newton is engaged. Alice MacChesney is in the movies. Don't know what company. She wears better clothes than anyone else in town and runs her own motor car. I believe that's all
Completed

the gossip I can think of. Doc is still in Chicago. He came out Sunday and spent the night. Seemed much pleased with the place.

 Have had lots of rain lately and very cool weather. Much warmer today but such a high wind blowing one can hardly walk. Had a very hard rain in the middle of the night. The drops sounded like gravel coming down on the roof.
 Found the film of Grandma Bell and will have the prints made and mail all according to directions  Did you receive the money that Max mailed you about a week ago? Perhaps it wasn't quite so long ago as that, but you should have it by now.
 Puss tat is very happy in his new home and enjoys prowling about the yard.  So glad you are feeling better, Grandma.   Don't work too hard on the portieres. It is lovely of you to make them for me. I will send the silk as soon as possible.    Lots and stacks of love,  Katharine
Completed

On board the Good ship Virginia. Goodrich Line.  Enroute to Muskegon.

[5-29-15]

Dearest Mummie & Grandma:

 You will be somewhat surprised to see the above from where I am writing - no more surprised than I was yesterday morning at Hub's office to get a letter from Nellie Zay saying that she had run a rusty nail into her foot and wasn't able to get about and wanted me to come and stay with her for a time. She didn't say how badly she was hurt so don't know how long I shall have to stay.  The boat hasn't left Chicago yet and people are still running up and down stairs with clashing keys and slamming suitcases. It has rained all day today and is still hard at it.  it seems as though I never saw a rainier spell in this part of the country. It is about as bad as no rain at all and the crops are at a standstill. As I came through the
Completed

vicinity of the Desplaines river today I noticed that the rains had made quite a la.e If it keeps on the tracks will be flooded. If I am not back within a week I will have Max or Margaret mail the silk pieces that I have collected. Mrs. Johnson said she had a number of things I could have but she hasn't given them to me yet.    Pusscat has been laid up recently with two swollen paws, one front and one hind one on alternate sides. I don't know what could cause them unless he has eaten something that was poisoned. He doesn't eat much except warm milk and sleeps night and day. He still limps very badly but I guess he will get well in time. He can't bear to have his paws touched. Bought a rug for the front room yesterday, a 6x9 axminster at $13.00. It was delived (sic) this morning together with the curtaining I purchased for three bedrooms and the library. Wish you could see it all. Am sure you
Completed

would like it. Got plain white curtains for the library with a pretty border which resembles drawn work & hemstitching. For the south room and got white with a narrow pink border or stripe about 6 inches from the edge, worked in a conventional design. For the east room the same except that the border is blue. For the diamond pane windows in the north room got a sort of net just plain white  Got these fixed before I came away. Ran them on a bar at both top and bottom and attached to the window frame. They look very pretty. We are about to start now and I say say with Tom (Do you remember Tom, R.H. Barbour's character in "Four in Camp"?)  the weather still continues wet.     xxxx

 In the meantime have sat out on deck until 9:30 and gone to bed. Am up now at 4:40. If I had known
Completed

how early it was I wouldn't have risen. Am all dressed and sitting in the cabin  I don't know when Ralph will call for me but there's no use going out and being all wet and uncomfortable. It is still raining. That makes about 36  hours at a stretch. I hope we won't have a repetition of the well-known flood of biblical times.

 Think I will give this to someone going ashore to mail.     With heaps of love,     Tafern.

Will drop you a card soon, letting you know how long I will be gone so you can know whether to address me here.
Completed

SUNFLOWER POULTRY FARM
   Strictly Fresh Eggs Our Specialty
        R.R. No. 4
   Muskegon, Mich.

June 5, 1915.
Dearest Mummie & Grandma:

 It is a quarter of six a.m. and the handiest time to write a letter on the above poultry farm. I've been quite an early bird for a week now and as I go to bed a couple of hours earlier than usual, I don't notice it much.  Nellie's foot is steadily improving and doesn't pain her nearly as much as it did. She is walking now, with out the aid of a chair, using the heel of her injured foot. She is very jubilant over the fact that her own special treatment (hot water and savina) made the consulting of an M.D. unnecessary.
 There are 250 big hens and 300 little chickens on the place, mostly white leghorns. The latter dine 5 times a day so what with feeding them and attending to the housework I am aplenty busy. At noon the cow and her eldest son come to the back door and put their noses in, setting up
Completed

a great clamor , to indicate that they are ready to drink all the water you may care to pump for them. Today is breadbaking day. I made a cake yesterday which turned out very nicely. It had no excuse for not doing so for I made it with real butter, fresh eggs and sour cream. We have real cream on everything, and very fine it is. The cow's younger son is  about 2 months old. He consumes vast quantities of skim milk, but we get all the cream. Got such a nice lovery letter from Max yesterday. It was quite a treat to read it. He wants me to come home right away. I expect I shan't stay longer than one week more so any letters you write that will arrive later than the 11th, had better be sent to Glen Ellyn. Was so glad to get your nice letter yesterday. Margaret forwarded it to me. Max said that on Decoration Day, He and Doc had dinner at the Kopp's and supper at the Schoenfeld's. He likes it very much in G.E. and thinks the
Completed

SUNFLOWER POULTRY FARM

   Strictly Fresh Eggs Our Specialty
        R.R. No. 4
   Muskegon, Mich.

people are "regular folks". He said he was going to play ball Sunday at Lincoln Park on a team which one of his paper salesmen belongs to. How I wish I could be there to watch him! I told him I wanted him to play again just as soon as I came back.

 Nellie Z. has sold her piano so I get rather lonesome for ours to play on. I went over to one of the neighbor's the other evening and played theirs for a few minutes but half the family had retired when I got there so I felt pretty squeamish about staying any length of time. The people our here just toil and labor all the time, stopping only to eat and sleep. Sunday is like all the other days. I don't see what the use of living is, if one has to spend all one's time that way.
 Wish you could see the eggs I gather every evening. They usually come to the brim of a large pail. when they are cleaned and assembled in large
Completed

baskets they look very nice. Max said in his letter that pusscat was all right again and I feel greatly relieved. I told you, didn't I, that his paws were swollen and that he could hardly walk? I'm very choice of my pusscat and should hate to lose him.

 We are having fairly decent June weather just now. Wish it were warm enough to go swimming. It must be lovely to be situated as you are so you can go in any time.
 I'll send those silk rags, Grandma just as soon as I get back. I want to get those that Mrs. Johnson promised me. Hope your rheumatism has permanently disappeared.

Have begun to read The Sea Wolf, Mummie. Have you read it? What do you think of it?     Lots of love,   Tairn
Completed

Muskegon, Mich.

 June 9, 1915.

Dearest Mummie:

 Will have time for only a postal card before the postman arrives. About the rug, I think green and brown predominate but almost any color will harmonize with it. The walls are papered in a brownish tone so the portieres can be almost any combination and will look well.   Expect to be home Saturday. Nellie's foot well enough for her to get around now, but can't wear a shoe.  Am getting quite lonesome for my hub

on side:  and he is for me. Address me at G.E. next time. Both your letters were forwarded to me.    Love to both     K.
Completed

Glen Ellyn, ILL

July 13, 1915

Precious Mum:

 Am writing from Margaret's house. could not find any of the weed you mention in our garden and have just located a sprig over here.
I feel that the enclosed is the kind you want and will gather and dry some today if the town contains any. The sun is hot today so it ought to dry readily.
Completed

i hope the baby will recover. May O'Toole's nephew 1 1/2 years, died yesterday of some similar trouble. It seems to be very prevalent
among babies. I wish I knew the cause of it.  Got a letter from Mr. Blake yesterday saying that he was obliged to go to San Francisco
and would not be able to visit me until September. Mummie, you are such a good lady to remember our anniversary. I don't think you
ought to spend your
Completed

time making me things which you probably need for yourself but of course I love to have anything that you have made.
Mrs. Johnson has promised me 2 silk petticoats and 2 kimonos for the portieres. Spent pleasant Sunday with the Sanguinets. Went swimming 
and took dinner and supper with them. The water was a little too cold to be perfectly comfortable but didn't stay in long enough to be shivery.
Completed

Expect papa next Sunday. Had a mess of beans from our garden yesterday. Tasted mighty good. Pusscat is very fond of them.

 Wish I could have a visit with you. We could find lots to talk about, couldn't we? Does it still continue warm? We haven't had

any really hot weather yet.

 Lots of love,
     Tairn.
Completed

Glen Ellyn, Ill.

 April 5, 1916

Dear Mother.

 Gosh goodness! What must have become of my letters to you? We are both fine as silk.

Margaret and I happened to be together when she got your card so I am using it.

Heaps of love
