John Rigby                                                                       West Palm Beach, Fla.

                                                                                             [July 1916]

PARK HOTEL                                                                 HOTEL KASKASKIA 

At Madison, Wis.                                                             At LaSalle, ILL.
                                            MADISON, WIS.
                                                                          
                                                                 Sunday Morning.

Dearest Mummie:

 Staying at the swellest hotel in Madison. Room and bath to myself. Feel quite like an heir to millions.

Saw grandpa yesterday. He is quite feeble and has a nurse at the house to look after him. His place is
beautiful. such a surprise to me. Went rowing on Lake Mendota after supper and got good view of the 
College grounds & buildings. Can't write more now as time is limited and pen is awful.

   Much love,   K.
Completed

M.M. Moore  Art Department                                                           K.K. Moore  Business Mgr.

                                                  M. M. MOORE
                                                 Photo Pillow Tops
                                                                                     Glen Ellyn, ILL.
                                                                                  March 13, 1916.

Dearest Mummie & Grandma:

 Went in town Saturday and met Miss Ross at Field's at eleven. She gave into my keeping a 36,000 word manuscript to be typewritten. she says it is a love story

told in the form of letters - a correspondence between two shut-ins - a man and a woman. None of her other stories have been accepted as yet but she has not 
given up hope and enjoys writing them just the same.

 In the afternoon, I went with Laura and Norine to the Majestic. Saw a good show. Mrs. Langtry was the star performer in a playette called "Ashes". She makes a

good appearance and seems to be a good actress, though the part she took did not call for any particular skill.   Glad the things reached you alright and hope the shoes have arrived by this time. The paper will come later.  Max did not have the time to get it ready last week. It will be sent
Completed

right from his office. Am anxious to know how the black oxfords fit.  I am enclosing buttons and braid. Couldn't get just the sort of braid you wanted, Grandma. Hope this will be all right and suit the purpose. If the buttons are not the right size  can exchange them. Will keep the slip until I hear from you.

 Yesterday was a beautiful day and Max, Mrs. Catlett and I walked to Lombard and back. Mr.Catlett stayed at home as he is not especially fond of walking and had a headache besides. Heard a meadow lark, several in fact, early in the morning and during the day.
 The puppy is growing fast. Is larger now than the average full grown fox terrier. I think she will probably weigh about 90 pounds when full grown.
 The next dance at Odd Fellow's Hall is to be a leap year affair. The ladies have to take the gentlemen and ask
Completed

M.M. Moore  Art Department                                                           K.K. Moore  Business Mgr.

                                                  M. M. MOORE
                                                 Photo Pillow Tops
                                                                                     Glen Ellyn, ILL.

for all the dances. I'll guarantee that the women will thoroughly enjoy the occasion. They can dance as often as they like and with whoever they please. What bliss not to have to endure the trippings and skippings of a poor dancer. There is one thing about this crowd down here, though. Nearly all of them are good dancers and very pleasant people. Only three or four of the men can't dance and they aren't troublesome except in the circle two steps when it is a matter of chance who your partner will be.

 Do you think that Richert will be able to pay for the place after all?  If so, will you go up to Highlands anyway this summer? Wish you would both come up here instead. Wouldn't we have some glorious good times?
Completed

Mummie, are you still a substitute teacher or have you a regular appointment? Is it necessary for you to pass an examination to teach?

 Was much interested in your M.C. program. Is the home talent pretty good or mediocre?  How did the young man render the "Mother" song? It was very popular in Chicago about three months ago and was sung in almost every vaudeville act where they could squeeze a song in edgewise.
 I attended a meeting of the Socialist Womens League last Saturday at the Masonic Temple. Comrade Madsen spoke on Socialism, tracing its growth from the time before Marx and Engels appeared on the scene, and mentioning all the men who took an active part in developing the movement. He told more of the history side than you here in the average lecture. Saw a number of people you know, all of whom asked about you - Miss Pischel, Mrs. Howe, Mrs. Madsen, Mrs. Sissman, and Mrs. Kennedy.  Wish you were both here to take a walk with me now.   Lots & heaps of love      Tafern.
Completed

Glen Ellyn, ILL.

April 7, 1917.

Dearest Mum & Grandmum:

 Am writing this in the kitchen in the company of Babins and the gas oven. The fire is out though we expect to have one tomorrow. It still continues chilly. Have had only one warm day. All others around 38º. So glad you are doing well in the hotel.
 Babins is fine. Weighed 10 3/4 lbs. Thursday (9 wks. old). I played at the show last night - got him to sleep at 6:30 and didn't wake up till 1 a.m.  He laughs and coos lots now and smiles when we sing to him. He seems very fond of music. He often will lie still and coo while I play the piano. He sees very plainly but does not yet reach for things. He knows now when I am getting ready to nurse him and waits very patiently unless I take too long about it.
 Dropped in on Grandma S. the other day. Said M. is to leave Sears and get a job on the Board of Trade. She is to have $12 a week to start.  Don't know
Completed

yet about the kind of work she is to do.

 Haven't seen her for nearly 2 wks. she has been painting their kitchen evenings and always does housework on the Sabbath. She said she was going to send for "Aunt Annie in Omaha" some time this month, so when she comes M. will be able to get out more.
 Haven't forgotten about that Art & Craft business but don't seem able to get hold of a classified directory of names you wanted or will have Max get them.  Gloves arrived

safely. Many thanks. They fit beautifully and are a great comfort this cool weather.

 Babins always smiles broadly and "cheers and shouts" when moving his bowl [sic] or after spitting up food. They are his favorite diversions. He is contemplating the former now,

I think.
Completed

He is lying near me in his buggy looking at the ceiling x x  Just now woke up to be changed. Have to keep him quiet now by singing and rolling the buggy (while writing)
so you will excuse incoherencies. Was glad to see Aunt Althea's letter. How is Mrs. Wray's little girl?

 Hope you will find the hotel business a profitable investment. Perhaps some day you will be prop. of a regular Waldorf-Astoria down there.   
 Max is thinking of going in with another printing company - letting them use his machinery while he is to work on the outside altogether soliciting orders. He would get 15.00 per wk. salary and commissions (the latter would generally be much more than the salary)  I think it would be a fine arrangement because
Completed

he is good at meeting people and the work will be a pleasant change and take him out-doors more which is what he needs. I expect to get my spring coat, shoes, etc. at Sears as it is hard for me to get to town. Their prices are lower and their stock just as good as the things in the downtown stores.  Have to play again tonight and am trying to nurse Babins in such a way that he will sleep straight through as he did last night.

 I find I have failed to mention the all imp. fact that we are now at war but no one seems much stirred up over it. Glad Miss Rankin voted "no"!
 Think you had best have the addresses of your magazines changed as I have so little time for reading. Could stay in and read but prefer to take Babins out as much

as possible.        Lots of love,      Tafern.
Completed
Typical depression problems but related with good humor.
Completed

Friday afternoon
Dear Mummie

 Am sending you the yarn for tights  by this mail.   Did not get the brand you asked for but got the kind that I used for the sweater and sufficient to make the leggings - tights

or whatever they are called - so the saleslady assured me. Went to town yesterday and got stockings for Malcolm, gloves for myself, gingham 2 1/4 yds. each of blue and tan for suits and 1/2 yd. picque for collars.    Just rec'd a very pretty
Completed

page out of order
do such a stingy thing if I had a job.

 M's measurements are
    waist    25 in.
 from " to ankle    23   in.
 crotch   "    "    15 1/2 "
Max put the storm windows on last Sunday. It is warm today  - 62 [degrees] just now.
 I see by your calendar that this is Verne Sheridan's birthday - 36 years old apparently - just a year older than Max. Would send her a card but don't know her address.
 Have added quite a number of new stories to my list lately - Malcolm will listen to one any time -
Completed

page out of order
organdie collar trimmed with tatting for Miss Ross, and am writing a note of thanks immediately. It is too late for a birthday gift and too soon for 
Christmas but is quite welcome nevertheless.

 The yarn came to #3 00 so am enclosing $2 00 bill - the balance of the $5 00  Do not like to take it out of the rent money in that manner, but

hope can afford to make up for it by and by. Guess you know I would not
Completed

the more I will tell, the better pleased he is.   He knows the story of Perseus and the gorgons - of Pegasus, - the Pied Piper of Hamlin - Columbus and his
discovery of the West Indies  Alladin and the lamp, Sara Crewe, Little Lord Fauntleroy - Little Lame Prince and also the story of your childhood adventure with the flatiron heater. He also likes to hear me recite Seein' Things and Jes fore Christmas.   Read the poem of the Pied Piper to him last night and he seemed to grasp the meaning very well. 
Shall be interested to hear how you found things in A. P.      Love, Katharine.
Completed

Glen Ellyn, ILL.

Sept. 24, 1920

Dear Mummie -

 Your letter arrived together with nightgown which I like very much and am thanking Grandma for it in a separate letter.
 I am mailing the pine needle sack today - I have dropped your rubbers into same, and hope the whole will turn up safely.

The needles protrude a bit here and there from the sack and I am wondering whether the P.O. will accept it. I may have
to put into another less porous sack.
Completed

You have not mentioned canned fruit in your assortment of articles to go south. shall send cherries and tomatoes. Have 19 quarts now on
hand of the latter and the vines look as though they were still good for a like amount. Have them to eat every day besides those canned.
Most of them are very large and weigh a pound each. shall I send 3 extra photographs of the "4 generations" which Mr. Thomas took?

 Miss Ross came Wednesday at about 3 o'clock in the afternoon. I had
Completed

looked for her at 12 and did not eat lunch until a quarter of 2. She explained that she had come on the northwestern with the Lewises and some
other ladies who were bound for a picnic at Elmhurst so she was planning to take the Electric to Glen Ellyn from there but attended the picnic
instead after attempting to reach me by ' phone. She stayed to dinner and had a little auto ride after dinner. I invited her to remain
Completed

overnight, but she decided to take the 8:30 train home. I went to bed after she left and knew no more until I heard her voice calling me, announcing that she had come back.
Said she waited until 9, and the train had not come. While she was talking, the train came.

 She took the 8 o'clock train in the morning and I loaned her my monthly ticket mentioning that I would like to have it back so as to go in Friday. she said she would mail

it back as soon as she got off the train, but I have not
Completed

yet received it. it it doesn't come tomorrow I shall have to write for it, I guess, and jog her memory. She was to visit Mrs. Marshall in the morning,
getting off at Kedzie avenue.

 She plans to return to Kalamazoo next week. I'm afraid the above narration sounds like a tale of woe, but I have not meant it to be. I enjoyed

talking with her very much. She is easy to entertain as she asks for what she wants and makes herself comfortable. She gave me a recipe for apple
Completed

sauce cake and showed me a new way to fix round steak - much as you fix it except that it is cooked slowly over the top of the stove, instead of in the oven.

 I see you had not received my letter when you wrote. Max's trunk, or rather Sam's, is plenty big to hold nearly all the stuff you want so I should think my

little trunk, which is in pretty good repair - would be better to use than yours, but will do what you think best.  when do you expect to reach Avon Park and
on what date had I better
Completed

plan to send this luggage?  You would hardly want it to get there ahead of you as some of the things ought to be unpacked as soon as possible.

 I have to play at the show tonight so must stop.     Much love,        Katharine.
Completed

Glen Ellyn, ILL.

Sept. 30, 1920

Dear Mum and Grandmum:

 Your welcome letter just received, 1:30 p.m. The postman grows later daily (if you get my meaning) and I presume by Christmas he will be calling at midnight.
 The bubble pie, frog, fish and boat arrived yesterday and were received with much acclaim by the small gentleman. I fixed some bubbles right away and he

blew some remarkable ones right away and enjoyed himself hugely all afternoon. He rushed down to Buddie's to bring him up, and returned with
Completed

both brothers, and displayed his new things with much pride. The boat, and the acquarium were put to float in the sea of bubbles and "a fine time was had by all".
The pipe fills a long felt want. I tried to get one here in town but could not and as I have not been to Chicago Malcolm was languishing for the want of one, and 
mentioned it daily. He was to write a letter to thank you today, but is now calling at the Feist home.

 My ticket (the one I loaned Miss Ross) has not yet
Completed

appeared. It will be no good to me after today so I may as well forget about it and buy a ten-ride. A letter of explanation from her, however, would be appreciated.
I wrote her day before yesterday, to jog her memory, but nothing has come of it yet.

 Glad you are having such a pleasant visit. It turned quite cool early yesterday and I have had a fire in the grate yesterday and today. We have sufficient coal for

the fireplace but non has been delivered yet. Max intends to see them regarding it
Completed

some time this week. Went down last night but office was closed. Glad the pine needles came through safely. The Division of Agriculture circulars came today.
Am going to send for several of them.  Am mailing the literature now on hand which has accumulated since you left.

 Had a call yesterday from Mrs. Louis. Was disappointed to learn you were not here. Stayed about half an hour and chatted about various matters. Seems quite spry. Says she is 86 years old.
 I see Margaret nearly every day. Will tell her
Completed

what you said about having her urine examined. Did I tell you that the farm folks have no more eggs for us? They say they have only enough now for their own use. 
They said they would let us know whenever they have some to spare.

 Enjoyed seeing the letters from Elsa and Mrs. Thomas. What an intense young woman Elsa is, isn't she?  Right in touch with the world world all of the time and

glorying in it.  I hear Malcolm coming and will let him add his contribution.      Much love,      Katharine.
Completed

Glen Ellyn, ILL.
[October, 1920]
Monday Morning
Dear Mum & Grandmum:

 Your two letters arrived in the same mail with one from Miss Ross explaining the mystery. It seems she mailed the ticket at the N.W. depot the same morning that she

went in from here and does not understand why I failed to receive it.  I suppose it got lost somehow.

 Was very glad to have your ticket and enclose ten dollars in payment.  Max thinks we can manage to send $5 00 weekly as a sort of rent money - of course

not what the place is worth, but it will be better than nothing
Completed

so you may look for it each week in my letter.

 Malcolm, with my assistance planted the scarlet sage as soon as your letter came, and has watered it several times since. He has never asked for "the chicken book"

but quotes from it frequently - thus: "Good morning", said the morning glory seed to the chick. "Oh", said the chick, "are you alive?" - or words to that effect.

 I potted the pink geranium in the garden about a week ago and I think it will do pretty well. The blossom is small and the leaves are small and have very short stems.

I suppose
chicken book
Completed

it needs fertilizing. How would some manure from Mrs. Kopp's chicken house do?

 What were the things we were going to get from the Bruning's Nursery?  It is now time to go after them.   We had a little picnic in Lincoln Park yesterday -

drove in and carried our lunch, the mail feature being fried chicken purchased from Mrs. Feist. Malcolm still coughs about as he did when you left. I presume it
will hand on for some time. I am mailing some literature that has accumulated.    We are getting a few
Completed

fresh eggs from the Kemp place. He is living on the other side of town now but his outfit remains where it was and some people from Chicago have moved in,
who are going to run that end of the work for him.

 When Malcolm goes off to Carl's, he bids me goodbye, with some speech like this" "Goodbye, be a cheerful woman. Be brave. Have a good time at home."

Then I am to respond - "Have a good time at Carl's."   Must stop now and go over town.    With much love       Katharine
Completed

Glen Ellyn, ILL.
Oct 14, 1920
Dear Mummie:

 I presume you are in Chattanooga by this time, so am addressing you there.  Enclosed find the weekly $5 00. Am going to

see the furnace man today when I go down to mail this.

 I'm sure you will have a fine outing and will be anxious to hear all about it. Mrs. Spink must be a very congenial lady.
 How soon shall I ship your goods? If they are to go by freight they will
Completed

probably be a long time on the road.

 We have been enjoying some unusually warm weather for this time of year, but the weather man has prophecied its finish by this evening. It is now 72

while recently it has been as high as 85 at this time of day - 2 p.m.

 Will get after the currant bushes as soon as possible. The Curtis pony is no longer pastured near us, and even while she was, I never noticed any manure in

the field. Would chicken manure be of any use? This was in connection with
Completed

the pie plant. did you know that the Pheiffer's had sold the lot next door? It seems they sold it a year ago to a widow by the name of West. I met her Tuesday.
She was looking at the lot and asked me if I lived here. I was out in the yard taking in the washing. She has a large family of children most of them grown and lives in
West Moreland - just east of Lombard on the Electric. She intends to have part of the lot plowed up this Fall and will put out
Completed

some fruit trees and next Spring may build. She said she would probably have the house as near the corner as possible, so I don't think it will cut off much of our
light. I guess she has seen some pretty tough times, as her husband died 15 years ago, when her children were not self-supporting.

 I have planned to put all the geraniums in a long box which Max will construct and have it in the bay window. Then it can be on the porch next summer. The other plants
Completed

I will repot and distribute about the house to the best advantage.

 I think it is going to rain so must stop now and go over town.
   With much love      Katharine
Completed

Dear Mother,

 The carrier came before I could write more. He brought the letters from J.C. enclosed. I wrote to have your pension forwarded to J.C. as I thought if I waited

they might think there is something wrong. They are always so suspicious at Washington.

 Daddy still in bed this a.m. tho he is no worse. Just a little bowel trouble and night-mare. My opinion is that he is scared to die.  Mr. Long tells me that he

is very insulting to the people
Completed

I don't know when we can get to Chattanooga - not until Daddy is up and around all day - I have sent word to K. to start our goods by freight
soon as convenient -  I enclose a clipping for Chas. Tell him to inquire about the examination -

 We expected to have a little ride yesterday, but Spinkie felt too sick to go when the $200 horse(?) and ten cent wagon arrived, so she
Completed

page out of order
around here and made an enemy of everybody when he first came.  Says the old lady has few friends because she is such an old blowhard, and nobody around here likes Guy.  Don't say anything about it tho in your letters, for while I am to destroy them all, she might find them before I do.  Am going now over to Mrs. Templetons to carry a steak, as Mr. Long butchered a fine
Completed

critter yesterday aft.   We have the tail for soup for Daddy, a 5 lb pot-roast, a big Porterhouse steak, several pounds of nice ham and some eggs, five loaves of baker's bread and two kinds of bakers cake and a mess of mashed potatoes in the house.   And Daddy sick, and she nearly so.  I wish the Charlie Spinks would come to eat things up.
Completed

sent the two hundred dollar horse back home.

Glen Ellyn, ILL.

 Oct. 30, 1920.

Dearest Mummie:

 Am writing hurriedly as we are all ready to go downtown to purchase a roast of lamb in honor of Grandpa Kerr's visit tomorrow. It will be the first time I have

seen him since last spring. Guess he has been well and busy. Called him up at the office and invited him out the last time we were in town.

 Got a box for your things after several unsuccessful attempts, and hope to get it packed
Completed

tomorrow morning. May decide to send canned fruit separately as if it should break the damage would no doubt be considerable on account of the length
of time on the road.

 Got two pails of dirt from the woods yesterday for the flower box and have a little left over to use for other plants. Put the 6 birthday geraniums in the box

and they fill it up comfortably. Looks quite well.

 Most forgot to tell you
Completed

we have a pup (airedale) acquired last Sunday. Malcolm takes quite an interest in him and when he is house-broke will do very well. Has
a smooth coat (at least more so than Pupsie's was) and has no Mange. Looks very well - is friendly to us - hostile to most strangers and
especially to dogs. Is not quite three months old.

 Must stop. Find check enclosed.
         Much love           Katharine
Completed

Glen Ellyn, ILL.

 Nov. 5, 1920.

Dearest Mummie:

 The box started on its journey yesterday. Enclosed find bill of lading, and the weekly $5 00
 Had Margaret and Austin over for dinner last night. Had roast chicken with stuffing, mashed potato, stewed celery, grape & nut salad and

birthday cake with coffee.    Had a cocoanut cake and garnished it with 35 candles. Much obliged for Max's present. 10 1/2 is right size and he
Completed

always needs socks. They have not arrived yet - will probably come this noon.

 Hope everything in the box will go through all right    It was a big one and there was more than enough room for everything you enumerated.

I put in the walnuts and the umbrella and the rags for rugs and all the bedding you asked for as well as the grey U.S.N. blanket which you
failed to mention (wrapped up the small mirror in it - the one like
Completed

the one in the kitchen. The clock was packed between the two pillows which were in your trunk and I also put in the small pillow and case that you used
on your bed - sent pad as requested - also opera glasses, as we don't use them at all here.    Sent cover that was used on porch swing as thought you would
need it for your porch cat. - also table cover of similar material. The hot water bottle has sprung a leak at one of the seams and if it cannot be mended, will
buy you a
Completed

new one and send parcel post. Have a number of papers to forward - appeal, Pathfinder, etc.  Shall I mail them to J.C. or do you want to receive them later
at A.P.? Glad you intend remaining in J.C. for a while longer, as it will take a little over a month - no doubt - for the box to get to A.P. and you couldn't keep
house very comfortably without it.   If, on unpacking it, you find anything has been omitted that you need, - let me know and will
Completed

forward at once.

 Had a nice visit with Papa Sunday. Had roast lamb, etc. for dinner and cream pie for dessert. Took him for an auto ride in the afternoon. He brought me

a new book of short stories by Jack London and said would send me about a dozen other volumes that he has in addition to the ones now on the shelves
here. Shall have to build an addition onto the book case, I think.
Completed

Malcolm talked with him nicely and seemed to enjoy his visit. M. is real well but still has a cough that I don't know how to get rid of. He eats lots of
fruit and is outdoors nearly all of the time. He doesn't spit up, nor whoop nor cough very often, but it is still with him. I don't think there is any cure
for it and will probably leave him in time.

 Have had several frosts lately and temperature as low as 30. Yesterday
Completed

it got up to 58 and now is 45. Plenty of sun and snappy air. The pup is male - would not have one otherwise. Are still hesitating on a name -
Jimmie - Bill - Rags - Hooch - Poilu (meaning whiskers) all are under consideration. Meantime we call him Pup and probably will continue to do so.
Malcolm still plays with Buddie to the exclusion of all others. He calls on Margaret frequently, but goes nowhere else unaccompanied.
Completed

Got down the Peg Board for him the other day with a few pegs for a try-out, but find he is still too young to enjoy it.  I believe the sewing cards might interest him and
will get some next time we go to town. I fear some of our bills were forwarded to you again by mistake although I notified the Natowa Dairy to change the name to
ours. Got an announcement of the marriage of Ed Pressprich to Edna Bortner - the girl he has
Completed

been going with for some time. She used to live in Roselle and is now in Batavia. Max met them on the street in Chicago the other day and says they intend living
in Park Ridge.

 Was much interested in the pictures you enclosed and will return them in my next letter. The one of Grandma "sneaking the pumpkin" was especially good and

quite characteristic of her enterprise. Glad she is feeling better and able to go around and enjoy herself.   Must stop and go to town.

  Much love,   Katharine
Completed

Glen Ellyn, ILL.

 Nov. 11, 1920

Dearest Mum & Grandmum:

 We are having a small flurry of snow this A.M. as I write & it is now 32 (degrees). Was 25 earlier in the day. Has been no colder so far. get a little

coal now and then - enough to last us. Expect 2 tons of the ILL lump today - $10 25 per ton.  I believe the hard coal is still $18 00 or more - quite
beyond our purse.

 Did I tell you that
Completed

Papa invited us to dine with him on Thanksgiving Day? We are to stroll through the Park - then go to his favorite eating house on Clark near the Park. He calls
it Vogelsang's but it is no relation to the place by that name in the loop. Its chief attraction is that it is inexpensive. They usually have an assortment of three dinners
to choose from and Papa takes the lead, choosing the least expensive and what can the guests
Completed

do but follow suit? I'm going to take turkey this time, though, if it appears on the bill-of-fare. He is generous about books, anyway. Believe I told you that he
is going to send me a dozen more of Jack London's.

 Sorry you were troubled again about the bills. I certainly forgot to mention the change to either Saunders or ? and the milk people are the only ones I

notified, and I fear they did not pay any attention
Completed

as I have not received the bill for this month.

 Ordered some Christmas tree ornaments from Sears which arrived yesterday. Got 4 dozen assorted glass ornaments for $2 67. These will last a long time

and are very pretty - well worth the money. Malcolm has looked at them many times and is anxious for Christmas to come.

 Eggs are 81 c per dozen now and hard to get. The storage seem to be good quality, however. Ate one for lunch yester-
Completed

day and while the flavor was not all that could be wished for, it was edible anyway.

 Max's sox came last Saturday and they are very nice indeed. He was much pleased with them. He did not hear from his Mother since some

time in July.    He did rather a remarkable thing last night. Perhaps you remember his mentioning one of his teeth that bothered him - an upper
double tooth next to the one that
Completed

was pulled when he was a boy. Well, after dinner last night he remarked that he would go down cellar and look at the fire. In a few minuted he came back with
a pair of pliars in one hand and his tooth in the other. He had pulled it himself and there was a deep hole in the gum where the tooth had been. He spit blood
into the sink for awhile, but it finally stopped bleeding and will be all right, I
Completed

guess. I didn't believe he had done it until I looked into his mouth. The tooth had no decayed places in it, and was not loose. He said he had gone up to
Dr. Boughman's after getting off the train but found the office closed. Dr. B. does not do extracting, so it is just as well that he did it himself.

 The fire whistle has just started up - must stop now and darn socks.
     Much love    Katharine
Completed

Nov. 15, 1920
Dear Mum:

 Am dashing this off while waiting for my wash water to heat.
 Ed McChesney called the other day to call attention to the fact that the insurance on the place is nearly expired and asking whether we wished to renew for the same

coverage or an increased amount. If you can afford it, I think it would be ell to insure for at least $3000 00 for just as he says, it would not be possible to build
Completed

a place like this for $2000 00 and 4000 00 would be better. The rate is $8 50 per thousand so premium for $3000 00 would amount to $25 50, for the three years.
He said he would keep us covered for $2000 pending word from you.

 Will get the yarn you mention as soon as I can get to town. Am knitting Malcolm a cap to match his sweater so he won't have to wear mine. Shall need it myself,

as have nothing else except
Completed

my beaver hat that is suitable for winter weather. Had already gotten a hot water bottle to send you. Cost only 78 c but seems very satisfactory. Does not
leak and looks like good rubber, so will send along and you can use until you get the aluminum one.

 Margaret is in very good health now. Works quite hard about the house but has not done any sewing yet for the baby. Her Mother-in-law has given her

7 white dresses that were used for Austin in his infancy so she will not need
Completed

need to worry about that part of the outfit - and she is buying the diapers already hemmed so the petticoats and blankets and nightgowns are about
the only things she will have to make. Still, she ought to get at it right away. I look for the baby at least by the 1st of January and possibly sooner.

 Remember me to Fannie Reeves. Will try to write her soon.    Hope you will find things in good order.
     Much love     Katharine
Completed

Glen Ellyn, Ill.

 Nov. 29, 1920.

Dear Mum:

 My letter is late, as I have been waiting to receive insurance policies to send you, which I now enclose.   He made out the first one for $2,000 just to keep

the place covered while waiting to hear from you, and added the other thousand on receiving your check. I asked him about the description "frame building" 
and he said all stucco houses as well as clap-board, come under this head. The other classification is brick or stone, I presume.
Completed

Hope the fruit will net you good returns this year. Sugar is down to 10 c a pound - 8 c with a $2 00 order at the Fair and such places. 
Eggs are now 93 c -however. Mrs. Kopp said she might have a few fresh ones to sell me soon. Her pullets are beginning to lay.

 Had a very pleasant day with Papa. Went to the usual dinner place, but fared very well. Had tomato soup, Turkey celery, cauliflower, potatoes,

bread & butter, New York ice cream, cake & coffee. Cost Papa $1 25 per each. At the Park saw the new baby hippo presented recently by
Completed

Wrigley, the gum man. Has a spacious apartment in the bird house at the farther end, next door to the ostriches. Has private swimming tank. Was dozing when we saw it.
After dinner we went to a movie which was quite good. Malcolm napped here for part of the time. When we got home Mrs. Kopp came over and said Mrs. Curtis wanted me
to play at the show as she had company and couldn't get away. It was then after six o'clock. Mrs. Kopp sent over some fruit cake
Completed

for our supper and I managed to get down to the show only a little late. Saw a very good picture - Wallace Reid in "Sick Abed". Very funny. You must see it if it gets to the Park.
Does the same man still run it? I forget his name. Glad to hear about Maude Burley.  Give her my love. And what a time Fannie had! Will write her soon. Hope she will be able
to punish the villains in the plot.

 Very dark today. Did not wash. Have got one suit for M. nearly done. I'm very polky
Completed

work at it only occasionally when can get at it properly . Will take his picture in it when done so yu can see how it looks.

 Was glad to have the snap shots. Malcolm looked at them with much interest. Asked who Uncle Charley was then identified

the others as "My Greatgrandma and my Walden grandma". He is now 40 1/2 inches tall and weighs 40 lbs. This is the correct
height and weight for a child 4 1/2 years old according to the U.S. child welfare card that I have.

 Have finished Malcolm's
Completed

cap except for putting on the tassel.   Have not seen Lillian Thomas for a long time - ever since I have been home. Expect to see her in a few days, however, as Max
has something in a bottle that is either whiskey or brandy which will do to return to her for that borrowed when he was sick. See Mr. T. occasionally on the street.
Never mind about the gaiters if you are too busy to make them. You did fine work on Uncle C's sweater. It fits him just like a bought one and I expect it was a big job.

 Love,  Katharine
Completed

Glen Ellyn, ILL.

 Dec. 3, 1920.

Dear Mum & Grandmum:

 This is a lovely day - what is so rare as a day in December? Temp is 60 (degrees) at present and nice sunshine. We were told in the paper, two or three days ago

that we were to have a blizzard, but none has come as yet.

 Went up to see Mrs. Thomas the other day, returning her brandy and taking some pictures to be developed. They are all well, Arthur is growing and looks bright and well.
Completed

Note - page out of order
age -  Thought I might be able to pick up some sort of present for him at the bazaar. Ethel is entertaining all the club girls that have children, so I am looking
forward to meeting some that I have not seen for a good many years.

 Don't know whether I mentioned in my last letter that we are dining with Margaret this coming Sunday.
 Have you seem Gene Woodruff yet? Tell him Miss Third Generation send her regards.    Malcolm has had his hair cut only once since you left
Completed

She spoke of having heard from you frequently and seems to enjoy your letters.

 Got a sacque to Margaret's baby at the Congregational Bazaar the other day - one that Mrs Kopp made. It is flannel and trimmed with crocheted edge and

cherry colored ribbon.

 Expect to visit the M.E. Bazaar today (this is the last one)  Had a letter from Ethel Holmgren yesterday inviting Malcolm and myself to a party she is giving for

her older little boy, Edwin.  I think he is about Malcolm's
Completed

Note: page out of order
so think that Tuesday (the day of the party) will take him to Mandel's for a cut and a curl.

 Ordered a pair of corduroys from Sears for Malcolm some time ago. Asked for size 4 - had to send back -

too small. size 5 ordered today. Also too small, so am sending them back. Hope size 6 will fit him. The leg is
long enough in the size 5 but too small in waist band.

 Must stop - wash dishes and go to town.      Much love     Katharine

Sent you a letter other day  Helen Frank had asked me to forward. Got mislaid & forgotten
for 2 weeks. Sent her my apologies.
Completed

Glen Ellyn, ILL.

Dec. 12, 1920.

Dearest Mum:

 Enclosed find check - a little late, but gives me an opportunity to answer your letter which I found in the box this morning.

Do not think you need worry about the tights fitting Malcolm. They are stretchable, and besides these corduroys were
unusually small and quite stiff. Will limber up when washed. The six year size fits him pretty well - not more than half an inch
too long in the leg and none too large in the waist.

 When in town last Tuesday, tried to get the yarn you wanted but they did not have it. Expect to go in tomorrow and will then

get some at another store, if possible. Did not have
Completed

time to go around much Tuesday. Went to the party in the afternoon and enjoyed it very much. Met a  number of girls I had not
seen for a long time. Ethel's eldest was 3 that day, but quite big for his age. The other just learning to walk. Mary Lowe - (I knew
her at High School) is the mother of a tiny six weeks old boy. She had him with her. Is a good baby. Then Elsie Hess, one of the
club members has a boy just a year old.  Elsie's sister Elaine is to be married next week. She is now president of the club.  Ruth Nelson has a little girl about six months old -
very pretty baby - and last but most peculiar, Mary Donnel, who was the very unpleasant member of the
Completed

club, has one of the handsomest and best behaved little girls I ever saw - three years old. She has beautiful features, long blonde curls,
and a nice disposition. I'm glad Mary made good as a mother, anyway.

 There were a number of other girls at the party, with their children, neighbors of Ethel's whom I had not met before. They were all very

pleasant and we enjoyed chatting with one another. Mrs. Holmgren, Ethel's mother helped with the refreshments and they had quite an
elaborate menu. Fruit cocktail, crackers, some kind of meat concoction in little pie crust dishes, pimento sandwiches.
Completed

icecream, birthday cake and coffee. The children had their refreshments served on the library table in the living room. Malcolm behaved very well and
seemed to enjoy himself.

 Will get the yarn for Margaret's booties when I get the extra yarn for the tights. The weather has been so mild he has not had to bundle up much.

Have not had Arthur Thomas over yet on account of his cough but Dr. Schiele says no other child could catch it now, so will probably have him over
soon. Gave him a pair of corduroys, size 4, that Sears sent extra by mistake. Think they will fit him nicely.

 Enclose some pictures - one that Margaret took and one that we took on the farm.  Will get one of Malcolm soon
Completed

in the new suit that I made. It turned out very well considering the fact that it was my first one.

 Sorry the box has not come yet. I gave the value at $300 00 so if it is lost, you can collect that amount. I doubt if you could replace

all the goods for that sum, but it will help. Will have agent send tracer, as you suggest.

 Have met the lady who lives at Mrs. Thomas's. She is very pleasant and Malcolm calls on her occasionally.  He makes calls more

frequently than I do.

 Max is still with the Type Founders and probably will be until something better turns up. I understand that a good many men have been
Completed

laid off, and this morning I fed a tramp - first I have encountered for quite a while.

 Am taking Malcolm in tomorrow to do his Christmas shopping - he has $5 00 to spend which he saved in his red bank.
 Hope you will not be horrified or too surprised when I announce that a baby brother or sister for Malcolm will be hatched

next Spring. Have not determined the exact date but have hired Dr. Schiele and expect to get Mrs. Lang for nurse. She has
taken care of Agnes Hoodley - Mrs. Mc - next door, Rose Dodge - and various others, so think she will do very well. Mrs.
Kopp says that Mrs. L. generally does some of the housework too.
Completed

so ought to get along all right. Max is much pleased and is very considerate - and Malcolm is much interested and has had much of the matter
explained to him. He asks daily when the baby brother will come and wants to know where in my anatomy he is concealed. I really don't know
just how far along I am - which may seem very queer, but the motion I have felt for the past three weeks at intervals, does not feel like any I have
felt before and may not be the bona fide thing.  Anywhere from April 1st to June 1st is rather hit or miss, but is as near as I can come to it now.
Completed

Can't remember whether my last sick time was in July or August, but have had none since August.

 Sorry Grandma has not been feeling just right and wish you had a good sidewalk to town. I can imagine what a task it is for her

to walk so far in the sand.

 Have a lot of your calling cards in a box here. Do you need them? You mentioned your shabby purse some time ago. Put your gold

vanity case into the freight box. It would be just the thing for the occasional social functions you attend.  I am feeling fine - no headaches
any more so don't worry about me.     Much love    Katharine
on side:
The pup is growing larger and is named Jerry.
Completed

Glen Ellyn, ILL.

 Dec. 20, 1920.

Dear Mum:

 So glad to learn that everything in the box came through in good order. Sorry now I did not pack some canned fruit, as there was plenty of room, but I was

afraid lest something should happen and if a can were broken, the juice would have ruined your bedding.

 Yes, I found the morphine - unwrapped the bundle to see what it was - then rewrapped it and replaced in the bottom of your trunk where it now is and can

remain until you want it.  Did not ment
Completed

Note: page out of order
Randall's death? He died more than a month ago - don't know just what the trouble was but he had been sick for a long time and they had a nurse for him
for quite a while.

 So glad you are sending some fruit. Shall be on the lookout for it. Temp. around 20º so told station agent to watch out that it did not freeze. Thank you

very much for your hard work in getting it off.

 Hope Grandma is feeling better. What shall I get for her birthday? Will she be 82?  Am mailing quite a number
Completed

mention it to Max or Malcolm and as neither ever goes into your room, am sure it is quite safe there. transcriber note: speaking about morphine from 2 pages ago

 Did I say anything about the Christmas tree ornaments that I got from Sears Roebuck? We have quite a large assortment now, for beginners, and I am quite anxious

to see how the tree will look. Expect to get it today.

 Max had a sick headache yesterday and slight fever so did not go to work this morning. Is out now taking a walk, also Malcolm is at Carl's so there is peace and quiet

aplenty. Expect Papa out either Saturday or Sunday.

 Did I write you of Mr. transcriber note:  continues on previous page; pages out of order
Completed

of Christmas cards this morning - among them one to Mrs. Marshall, Miss Ross and to Pattie. Am using the last address, 1566 Hawthorne St. for the latter and hope
either to hear from her or to have the letter returned so I can know definitely whether she is there.

 Malcolm is fine and can hardly wait for Christmas to come. I am going to give him the box of Mr. Poole's Woodman's Alphabet, as think he is old enough to play

with them. He can recite Jes'Fore Christmas and Seein' Things all the way through, with very little prompting.    Much love and Merry Christmas.     Katharine
Completed

12-24-20
Friday Morning
Dear Mum & Grandmum:

 We are indulging ourselves and having a turkey this Christmas. Papa will be with us tomorrow and Sam may drop in Sunday or thereabouts.
 Am making raisin bread today - completed a Christmas pudding two days ago and expect to get the turkey stuffed, ready for roasting tomorrow.
  Max and Malcolm are going to trim the tree tonight as I have to play at the show. did last night, too, as Mrs. Curtis's
Completed

daughter Esther came home after several months absence on her tour in the south.   Got a pickle fork for Margaret and took it and the baby sacque over
yesterday.     Got a card from Aunt Emma for Malcolm and this morning received a present for him from his cousin Martha (I sent her a sacque) but we are
keeping it to open tomorrow.   Got some pretty cards from Laura - one for Malcolm and one for his parents - also cards from Florence
Completed

Mayland, and Uncle Frank. Presume more are to follow as today's mail is not yet here.   Fruit not arrived yet but guess it will not freeze as they always put the fruit in
the waiting room at this end, to be kept warm. It was only 7 above this morning but has got up to 12º. Snowed quite heavily several days ago. Having nice
sunshine today so it looks as though we should have ideal Christmas weather.

 Hope you both are well and will enjoy yourselves mightily during the holiday festivities.    Much love   Katharine
Completed

Glen Ellyn, ILL.

 Dec. 31, 1920.

Dear Mum & Grandmum:

 On our very coldest day the lovely warm nightgown arrived, and was duly christened that night as the thermometer stood at 5 below. Many thanks Grandma dear.

It was the best possible present you could have given me as most of my nightgowns are thin, and a flannel one feels good on cold nights. The cold snap did not
last long, and it got up to 40 yesterday. We still have lots of snow left.

 The fruit came yesterday
Completed

and is in splendid condition. Only one grapefruit spoiled and none of the oranges. Expected only one case so was quite surprised and pleased to get two.
Malcolm is very fond of the oranges and has eaten close to a dozen already, besides one grapefruit.

 Glad to know you enjoyed the fudge. Tell Mrs. Godwin the recipe is very simple - to each cup of sugar use 1/2 cup milk, or less, small piece of butter and one square of chocolate. Then I used walnut meats, chopped fine. Any nuts will do, though.
 Have an accumulation of papers to forward to you, which
Completed

I have been saving until after the Christmas rush  Will try to get some off today.

 Papa spent Christmas with us, and brought a nice box of chocolates as w ell as $5 00 to spend for Malcolm and $10 00 for myself. Had a turkey for dinner

which was roasted very nicely (borrowed Mrs. Kopp's roaster) and lasted us until Monday.  Had suet pudding for dessert and have enough left for another
dinner. Expect to entertain Laura and Norine Sunday and may have it then.   Norine and her husband
Completed

are in Chicago for the holidays and may remain if he can get a position here. They have given up their flat in Detroit. I think she said they had to pay $70 00 for s bedroom, parlor and kitchenette and not the swellest part of town either. So many people are being thrown out of work by factories closing that it seems as though rents ought to
come down pretty soon.

 Spent Wednesday in town  Had lunch at Laura's with Norine, and Malcolm enjoyed himself very much. They have a beautiful Christmas tree just clearing the

ceiling (and their ceilings are very high)
Completed

After lunch we visited then I took Malcolm to the station to meet Max, who took him home and the girls and myself went to the Black Cat Inn for dinner and then
to The Storm at the Olympic. Enjoyed my outing very much, and hope to have others if Norine can remain in Chicago.

 That morning did a little shopping, spending my Christmas money. Got a pink silk negligee for $8 00, a house apron for 95¢ and a wash dress for $7 00. Max

had given me $10 00 to get something, so part of my money went for the dinner and show, and I consider
Completed

it well spent. Got Malcolm some kid mittens for $1 25 so he still has some left to spend.

 I want to thank you both for so kindly offering to help me with clothes for the new baby. Have nearly everything I need left over from Malcolm's wardrobe.

Diapers is about all I shall have to provide for the first few months, and perhaps a few blankets for the crib.  Expect to get a large crib that I can use for some time.

 When I need anything will let you know. The booties you gave me before are still wearable. That yarn I sent
Completed

was some I had in the house left over from Malcolm's sweater. I tried in a number of places to get more yarn but they were out of that color and did not know when
they would have it. The pink yarn I sent for Margaret's booties -  She is still at home and does not expect to be sick for two weeks yet.

 Malcolm received a number of presents - mechanical toy from his cousin Martha, a miniature bowling set from Virginia  a book from Laura, another book from

Margaret, a drum, toy telephone, and stationary steam engine from Max. Margaret gave me a pair of wool stockings and I gave her a pickle fork and a
Completed

sacque for the baby.

 Should like to go to the Firemen's Ball tonight but do not know whether I can get anyone to stay with Malcolm.   Guess I told you Malcolm planted some pumpkin 

seeds a while ago. They are now plants 4 inches high and have 3 leaves (There are 3 plants) all in the same flower pot.

 Glad to hear of your outing at Mrs. Marsh's and to learn about Martha and others.  Did not find the tree stand you mention. Got one for a quarter which did very well.

Have not heard from Pattie yet. wonder what ever became of her. Malcolm not much interested in alphabet blocks. Enjoys sewing buttons on cloth. Will soon try him
with sewing cards.    Much love     Katharine
Completed

Glen Ellyn, ILL.

 Jan. 11, 1921.

Dear Mum & Grandmum:

 Happy birthday to Grandmum. Am enclosing the present as it is likely not to arrive on time if sent in package form. It is not exactly what I wanted to get as had

in mind something embroidered on heavy linen white instead of ecru, but after looking at a number of places decided on this. They say this is not a good time of year
to get collars as the stock is run down.

 My remittance will go forward Thursday minus $1 00 for your share of the present
Completed

Don't worry about the tights.  We are having remarkably mild weather - has been with us since the 1st, and some people anticipate that it will continue to be mild

for the rest of the winter. Little colder today - 36 (degrees) - usually 40 at this time of day, 2 p.m.  Washed today as went to town yesterday. Got 3 bath towels,
some cretonne for south room windows and closet doorway, suit for Malcolm, some water glasses, stockings for myself and a handkerchief. Prices are a little lower.
the cretonne was 33 c per yard - very pretty 36 in. wide  Got 12 yards.
Completed

Malcolm enjoyed your stories of the clock and hen very much - also the poem. Just finished rereading them to him.

 He has the story of Theseus and likes it as well as Perseus. Have told the latter so often, as well as Pegasus that I feel much dismayed

at each necessity for a fresh repetition - fearing for my sanity. Doubtless you know how it is.

 He undresses himself very nicely but does not do much in the way of dressing. In warmer weather when garments are fewer can
Completed

probably attend to the whole process himself.

 Really heard from Pattie the other day. Enclose letter so you can see for yourself. Have asked her to visit me now rather than later as will be better able to entertain

her. Do not know whether she will come or not. you will notice she does not directly mention her husband so do not know whether she is with him or not.

 Expect to take lunch with Laura and Norine at Norine's on the 20th. Shall stop in to see Mr. Aehle the druggist and will tell you how our old stamping ground looks.
     Much love    Katharine
Completed

Glen Ellyn, ILL.

 Jan. 13, 1921.

Dear Mum: -

 Margaret called to me yesterday morning as I was going by, saying that she was having pains and expected to go to the hospital on the 10 o'clock train. Austin was

coming home to take her in, and she said she would have him let us know how she got along.

 This morning, while we were at breakfast, I heard a rap on the window. It was Austin who announced that Margaret gave birth to a 9 pound girl at 7:30 last night, and that they were both doing well. She is at the west Suburban hospital and will probably remain two weeks.
Completed

Her grandmother has been with her since sometime before Christmas and is now at Aunt Carrie's. May return when Margaret gets back from the hospital.

 I found some yarn, white on the table in your room which may be of assistance in making Margaret's booties. If there is not enough, don't use it, and I will

get some at the store.

 Am enclosing $9 00 as per previous letter.    
 The warm spell has somewhat abated though it is not bad at present -   25º  - looks like snow. Ground has been bare now since about the 28th of December.
Completed

Got Malcolm to take a nap today - the first he has had for a long time. His cough was worse last night though for the last week has been much better and seemed
to be vanishing.

 It breaks out worse on certain occasions and lasts for a week or so, then improves. Has not been bothering him at night until last night.
 He is waiting very impatiently for me to go over town so must stop. Hope Grandma is well and enjoyed her birthday.
             Much love     Katharine
Completed

Glen Ellyn, ILL.

 Jan. 21, 1921.

Dear Mummie:

 Enclosed find $5 00 bill. Hope Grandma got the collar O.K. Expect shall soon hear.
  Had another outing yesterday. Took lunch with Norine and Laura at Norine's. Met father and Alice. Then went in evening to hear The Famous Mrs. Fair

at the Blackstone. The Drama League is recommending it and it certainly is a fine play. The stars are Blanche Bates and
Completed

Henry Miller but the whole cast is excellent.

 Was talking with Edith Babcock, the girl in the A & P, today. She went to see Margaret yesterday and says both she and the baby are doing splendidly. 

She says baby has a lot of hair - very dark , nearly black. Thinks Margaret will be home next week when the two weeks are up.

 My letter to Pattie has been returned undelivered also the card I sent to
Completed

Note: page out of order
P.S. Papa was out Sunday. Expects to go south late in March.

 Do you remember what became of the small white bed we used for Malcolm when he was a baby? Do not believe it is on the premises. It would do very well

for the next one, at least for a year.
Completed

Note: page out of order
Los Angeles. I expected to find the latter coming back but am somewhat puzzled at the return of the other. Must be they left Detroit sooner than
they expected and we will hear nothing until she writes again  maybe 4 or 5 months from now.

 Have eaten up all the oranges. Have 4 g.f. left   Have enjoyed the fruit ever so much. Gave Laura & Norine some. They asked

to  be remembered to both of you and said they enjoyed the fruit immensely.    Much love   Katharine
Completed

Glen Ellyn, ILL.

 Jan. 28, 1921.

Dearest Mum & Grandmum:

 Much obliged for the apron. It is very pretty and fits me nicely, and it will be a great help, especially at this time when there are so few things that will fit me.
 Believe I failed to acknowledge the union suits and gloves. The latter are nice and warm. Have worn them several times. Have worn the heavy weight

union suits very little this winter - not more than three days - as it has been so mild am wearing oxfords with wool stockings most of the time. It
Completed

is lovely today - nice and warm and sunny - temperature now is 37 in the shade must be at least 45 in the sun. Quite different from our usual weather this time of the year.

 I enclose a newspaper clipping that you may be interested in.
 Bought some blankets from The Fair for $4.79. Seem nice and warm  Do not know whether there is any wool in them but believe they will be as warm as one of the

comforters. Expect to get some wool batting from sears as soon as I can, to make up the comforter to which Max's
Completed

Grandmother contributed.

 Have just cone from Margaret's. Took some mending over with me this morning and stayed a little while. The baby is doing very well, but causes the young mother

a good deal of worry for fear she is doing something wrong, leaving something undone, etc.

 her doctor has started the baby on a rather unusual feeding schedule - every 4 hours straight through the 24 - day and night. The baby seems to take kindly to it,

however, and in a good many ways it
Completed

makes it easier for her, or will, when she gets used to caring for the baby.

 I am feeling fine and am able to do quite a bit of work without getting tired - feel much more capable than I did in the beginning.
 Am expecting Helen out on Malcolm's birthday with George and John. shall have Cream Pie for the birthday cake, which will not cause

indigestion.

 Did I tell you that Grace smith has a boy 4 months old, as well as the other one? That makes 4 children for her now.
  Much love      Katharine

on side: Shall be glad to have the fruit if you can spare it
Completed

Glen Ellyn, ILL.

 Feb. 3, 1921.

Dear Mummie & Grandmummie:

 Many thanks for Malcolm's birthday gifts and letter. He was much pleased and prefers to put the money in the bank for the present.
 The fruit arrived on his birthday and is being much relished. Found the lemon from Mrs. Marsh's grove this morning. It was such a

big one I could hardly believe it was a lemon. shall make lemon pie with it - perhaps two as it is so large. Still have two of the galax
leaves you sent - threw
Completed

one of them out as it was quite withered.

 So strange that you did not receive the pruning shears and dust brush. Mailed them the afternoon of the day I received your letter - on a Tuesday.

I think. Forgot to mention them in the letter I wrote afterward.

 Entertained Helen and her boys on the 1st. Had bouillon, ham & peanut sandwiches, escalloped potatoes, fruit salad, cream pie with whipped cream

& cocoa, for the lunch. The boys are dreadful - no
Completed

page out of order
six months or so, they would be vastly different, as there is material to work on at least, in the older boy. He plays intelligently with blocks.  Have not seen many
glimmerings of intelligence in the younger child, but presume they are there. he is lively enough but has a very poor facial expression. so has John, at times.
I think one reason Helen does not seem able to manage them is that she has no opportunity to read.

Her husband has no
Completed

page out of order
two ways about it.  But I enjoyed my visit with Helen very much - as well as I could between the uproars proceeding from the boys.  If they could play
outdoors all the time they would be tolerable but in the house they do everything that children shouldn't do. They mind their mother only when please
and they don't "please" very often.

 However, if they could be put into a rigid institution for training young children for
Completed

page out of order
use for books - so she misses whatever current articles there may be on child training. Also, having them close together made it much harder.
Ah, well, we shall hope for the best.

 They are moving our in April and if I can get in closer touch with her I may be able to let drop a few hints or administer a little discipline myself.
 Mrs. Kopp's boarder, Mr. Allen, is no longer of this world. Died last Saturday evening at the hospital having been taken there
Completed

that same afternoon. It seems he had pneumonia. Dr, Higley attended him during his entire illness which lasted for 5 days - but did not seem to take much
interest in the case and did not diagnose it as pneumonia until he had reached the hospital - when it was too late. said he had a cold which didn't amount
to much - also spoke of neuritis - so he has another scalp on his belt. Mrs. Kopp did not know he was ill
Completed

enough to need waiting on so I guess for the most part he was left severely alone. His daughter Margaret may have been with him at the hospital as she was
in Chicago at the time. His wife and other three children were up in northern Wisconsin and could not be reached for some time after his death.

 The Kopps had the funeral at their house - another later at
Completed

the M E Church, with Mr. Kamp in attendance (that is, to marshal the autos, etc. Mr. Swaney did the preaching.)  I did not go over to the house, as I had
Helen out on the 1st and washed on the 2nd and the less pregnant ladies to to funerals the better off they are. They had a Masonic funeral with many white
aprons and gloves in evidence and stacks of beautiful
Completed

flowers. Well, we all have to die sometime but not all of us have to depart under such disheartening circumstances. Dont worry about the tights for Malcolm.
It is such a warm winter that he really doesn't need them. Next year will do just as well. Will try to send yarn for Margaret's booties sometime this week,
though may not be able to get it here. Do not expect to go to town again until after the new
Completed

one has arrived, as am getting rather cumbersome.

 Malcolm is fine - don't worry about his cough - it is growing very infrequent and is not at all alarming. he must weigh close to 45 pounds by this time.

He said the other day - "I have thought of a fine name for the baby brother - it is Tunsilu (Both u's with oo sound as in shoe)

 How much muslin will I need for two T bandages? Can only find
Completed

one around the house.

 Malcolm said when he was 4 he would wash & wipe the lunch dishes every day. He often makes funny excuses to get out of doing his work. Here is one -

"my elbow is so warm that I can't do any dishes and I will have to go outdoors." I asked him if he was often troubled with heat at the elbow but he took
it quite seriously. He is very clever with hammer and other tools. Pulled all the nails in the fruit crate and took the cover off himself with scarcely any help.

 Much love   Katharine
Completed

Glen Ellyn, ILL.

 Feb. 11, 1921.

Dear Folks:

 5 00 is enclosed, also tax statement which came a few days ago. Am not mailing it in the original envelope because it was quite flimsy, being the

window style without the isinglass effect. Taxes are awfully high this year on account of the new school. Our personal tax was $9 00 and Mrs. Kopp's
was $15 00 and Mrs. Curtis's was $25 00. Mrs. Kopp's regular taxes were much higher than yours, forget the exact figure.

 There have been two other deaths in town since last I wrote you - Mrs. Hudson, whom you will probably remember lived at the north end
Completed

of Main Street - died after a long illness. Perhaps you remember having seen her going around in a wheeled chair. Mr. McCormick was the other - a tall middle
aged man with grey hair for whom I did a small typewriting job several years ago. He hopped onto a street car on Wells St. and let his head stick out too far
and it struck one of the "L" posts. He died two days later.

 Caught 6 mice last week. Heard one rustling in the pantry and on investigation found three glasses of jelly had been devoured by them and part of the parafin

eaten away. Caught
Completed

5 in the pantry and one on the floor with one of those 5 c mouse traps.

 Have received my diaper cloth from Sears, also wool for comforter and some homely colored silkoline which I had to order from the description only. Shall keep

it but don't like it so far as the color is concerned.

 Malcolm is dusting some of the books for e. Has washed the dishes a number of times and does very well. Likes it much better than wiping them.
 He is going to the Episcopal Sunday School next Sunday. We went to one of their luncheons yesterday and had a
Completed

little talk with Mrs. Hiatt who teaches the infant class and she was sure he would enjoy it as there are a number of children about his age. The Feist children
are the only playmates he has and they have a number of undesirable characteristics, so I shall be glad if he can get acquainted with some other children.

 The dog is doing well so far as growing is concerned. He has all of Pupsie's tenacity for bringing things into the yard - foreign matter of all sorts, but mostly

bones and feathers. Do not know whether we can break him or not. The yard looks very untidy most of the time. Malcolm has planned
Completed

to cart the bones away to the ash heap in his wagon today.

 Have not seem Margaret for the past few days. Shall try to get down today for a little while. Will try to remember about that yarn today. Presume you

have lost all hope of ever seeing it.

 About the papers am saving for you - have taken off wrappers and find the following:
  6 Metamora Heralds dated from Oct 15th to Dec 3rd
  4 appeals from Oct. to Nov.
  2 Western Workers - Oct. 22 & Nov. 5th.
   There is also a sample copy of Pearson's Mag-
Completed

azine, the January issue. If you want any or all of them, will send.

 Have discovered some old M.M. Moore letter-heads which will come in handy instead of scratch paper.
 Must stop and help Malcolm with the books. Hope you both are well.
   Much love   Katharine
Completed

                                                                                                   Glen Ellyn, ILL.
                                                                                                     Feb. 18, 1921.

Dear Mum:

 Am enclosing customary $5 00 and am sending by this mail a skein of 3-ply saxony white yarn which I got at our local dry goods emporium.  If this will not

be enough for Margaret's infants' booties, I will get more at the same place. M's birthday is the 20th of March so it would be nice if you could sen them to
reach her at that time.

 Have forgotten to answer your question , put some time ago, regarding the yearly dollar from Jack Thomas. It did not come this time and of course, his

marriage is the reason, as a married man can hardly afford to distribute dollars at random among various adopted nieces and nephews.

 Malcolm has just gone to call on Mrs. Maurer. He is very fond of making visits which are usually very brief - 5 minutes or so at the most. He is back already,

bearing an orange and a rubber ball which
Completed

the lady bestowed on him.

 The Morse's daily Tribune (or someone else's) blew into our yard this morning, so I took possession and enclose picture of Wilson & his cabinet clipped

therefrom. His face (W's) is quite pathetic, I think.   He looks 20 years older than on the day of his inauguration.

 The book review has arrived and I shall enjoy reading it.
 Helen has offered to loan me the crib that she had for the children which is no longer in use. The springs are good and after a coat of enamel, it will look

quite respectable.  Of course I shall get a new mattress for it. Have part of the diapers hemmed and have started in on my house cleaning which will have to be
done early this year.

 Helen is coming our the first of March to help me put together my new comforter.    
 Margaret got her baby buggy a few days ago and has taken Betty out

a couple of times. She had to change the feedings to every 3 hrs. as every 4 hrs. was too long.

 Hope you both keep well.      Much love      Katharine
Completed

Your card just received.
    Ever so good of you to make T bandages and to send nightgown.  Did not mean to hint for you to make them as could have done it here.  Will be a great help

to have them all done, however. Very many thanks.

 Still have half a dozen g.f. left of last box but oranges have been "et".   
 Most forgot to tell you about our warm day.    Washed last Tuesday and at noon temp

was 65 in the shade. Said in paper 'twas warmest Feb. day in fifty years - ever since weather bureau was established.  30º today but plenty
of sunshine.
Completed

M.M. Moore  Art Department                                                                      K.K. Moore  Business Mgr.

                                        M. M. MOORE
                                         Photo Pillow Tops
                                                                                                   Glen Ellyn, ILL.
                                                                                                     Feb. 25, 1921.

Dearest Mum:

 After opening the package you sent, found that N could stand for "nursing" as well as "night". Many thanks.  The dress fits me beautifully and will be a great help

as one's wardrobe is always a problem at a time like this.

 Have been busy today cutting up the cretonne into curtain lengths, fixing silkoline for the comforter and also have cut up a months supply of inner diaper squares.
 Margaret called Dr. Schiele last night for the baby as she had a cough - caught it from Austin who has been home two days with a cold. They do not expect to be 

there after May 1st and probably will be with Mother Flett in Wheaton, who has decided not to go to England after all.

 Received the box of fruit very promptly - last Saturday. Thank you very much. Oranges are fine. Made a pie Sunday from one of the limes.
Completed

Temp. not as warm as has been but still warm for this time of year - runs from 25-35.

 Mrs. Kopp is well and is thinking of taking another boarder. Guess Mr. K's wages have been cut a little.  Everyone in his place had to be vaccinated a while ago or lose their

jobs and he is having quite a time as the result of the vaccination. Virginia came over last night for absorbent cotton.

 Fresh eggs now 45 a dozen. Still get a dozen every week from Mrs. Kopp. You should have heard Malcolm tell his father the story of Beleraphon and Pegasus the other

evening. He uses many long words - but all very correctly used and properly pronounced and the events are related in proper sequence with much gravity.

 Walked down to August Wolf's greenhouse at Taylor Avenue last Sunday and blew in 50¢ for a bunch of very beautiful sweetpeas. Hope I can raise some this year -

intend to get some pansy plants to set out in the lily-of-the-valley bed where you used to have yours. When ought this to be done?

    Much love, Katharine
Completed

M.M. Moore  Art Department                                                                      K.K. Moore  Business Mgr.

                                        M. M. MOORE
                                         Photo Pillow Tops
                                                                                                   Glen Ellyn, ILL.
                                                                                                      March 4, 1921.

Dearest Mum:

 Enclosed find customary $5 00. Yesterday was Apollo's birthday. Did you recollect it?
 It is after twelve and Malcolm's and my lunch time. We are expecting Helen and her boys any minute, but they may not be here for an hour or more. She wrote

that they intended to drive out with Herman, and might bring the crib.

 Have I told you of the new houses that are being built? There are at least twenty within a block of us - thirteen of them in the big lot just south of the old Phillips

place, at the corner of Hillside and Glen Ellyn Ave. (Park Blvd.). These 13 have a community garage in the rear of the houses - a long, low structure with an apartment
for each family. The houses are selling for around $10,000. I think Mr. Furman is the promoter and owns the land, I think. Two new houses are being erected next to
Mr. Tuneson's so our block is nearly full.  Another foundation is being dug at Hillside and
Completed

Forest across from Curtis's and the old corn field of the Dodge family has been divided into lots and is for sale. No building there yet. No signs of life yet on the
lot right next to us.

 Don't send me your nightgowns. I have 4 good ones and that will be enough. Do not think you had better send any more oranges as this box will last us quite a

while and then the rhubarb will be coming in soon. There some in the market now, but too expensive for us. Most things are cheaper. Eggs 45 a doz.

 Shall copy the recipes now and enclose them if can get thru before P.M. arrives, or company. If not, mail later. Many thanks for Erma's ticket. Sorry she is not

making payments on house regularly. Too bad to lose it as it is such a nice place.

 Helen's place is in a subdivision south of college avenue, about 2 miles. Wheaton Heighs, I think they call it. Handy by auto, but quite a hike.
 No, the Bruning's have not returned the borrowed books? Which ones were they? Have mailed you Pearson's and the followup letter they sent is inside the magazine.  Leggings rec'd. Many thanks. They fit nicely & are lovely & warm. Very windy today, temp. 40º.  Enjoying the oranges very much. Feel real well. Looking quite elephantine.   Much love,  Katharine.
Completed

M.M. Moore  Art Department                                                                      K.K. Moore  Business Mgr.

                                        M. M. MOORE
                                         Photo Pillow Tops
                                                                                                   Glen Ellyn, ILL.
                                                                                                    March 11, 1921.

Dearest Mum:

 Enclose find V. Sent more yarn for Margaret's booties the other day. Orange blossoms in your last letter smelled very good. Should like to see the trees. Ought to

have some kind of blossoms here pretty soon if the warm spell keeps up. Got as high as 62º today and has on several occasions lately. 

 My nurse called to see me yesterday. She is very nice and I'm sure I shall be well cared for. As I write, Mr. & Mrs. Curtis are just returning from the funeral of

Dorothy's youngest child - the little boy.  He was about a year old. Had eczema very bad - was under care of Dr. Boffenmayer, but finally died. The Dr. said his blood
was full of pus - so Mrs. Kopp said.   It seems Jean had a similar trouble except that hers affected the bowels, instead of the skin. Must be something wrong in the
family somewhere. You know 3 of Mrs. C's
Completed

children died in infancy.

 Well - about my nurse - she is much younger looking than I expected. Does not look more in years than her daughter, Mrs. Pulse. She said that my 4 nightgowns

would be enough - was pleased over the T bandages, and thought I had plenty of everything at hand for the baby.   She is waiting now for a woman to be taken who has
been expecting since Jan. 15th. Glad it isn't I !  I bought a lb. pkge cotton and large sized pkge gauze from Hillman's and expect to get enough oilcloth for my bed
and the crib. Then I will be pretty well fixed as soon as the newspaper pads are made.

 Helen failed to show up last Friday and have heard nothing from her. Guess I shall have to right [sic] and find what the matter is. When she hadn't arrived by 3 o'clock

I gave her up. started to work on the comforter and managed to get half of the tacking done. Have rolled it up and put away for another session soon. Plastering in
south room finished Monday. Max will calsomine in a day or two - then paint floor. Hope Grandma is well and you too.  Malcolm fine. Bought
on side

him a substantial spoon today to dig with.  Buddie is still his daily companion.           Love,  K.
Completed

Max has varnished library table. Malcolm's little rocker, small stand, front room floor - also painted woodwork in south room, stairs and front hall floor.  Are waiting
for plasterer to do some patching in south room - then Max will calsomine and paint the floor. expect to get a 6x9 grass rug for that room. Have bought mattress
for your bed for Malcolm to use.   Has been sleeping with me this winter.
Completed

                                                                                                   Glen Ellyn, ILL.
                                                                                                     March 18, 1921.

Dear Mum & G.M:

 V enclosed. Lovely spring day. 65º at present - 3 p.m. Have planted some sweet peas along the side porch and believe they will grow if I can keep the

dog from digging them up. Have stopped up the cat's hole with stones (he had enlarged it and was fond of retreating under the porch at times.). The ground seemed
nice and rich with plenty of angle worms and signs of manure. Seems to me Max put some on there last fall.

 Am thinking of having a telephone put in as may need it when Tunsilu is born. Expect to walk over to inquire how soon it can be installed, when I go to mail this.

Did a big ironing this morning and some darning. Then washed breakfast and lunch dishes and made two pies. Should do some cleaning this afternoon, but when
I am on my feet or bending
Completed

over slightly for any length of time, my back bone aches considerably. One wash day it was so bad that I could only hobble along in the evening and had some
trouble climbing the stairs. I find that if I lie down for an hour or so, that it relieves the trouble, if I wait until I can get my curves adjusted to the bed. It is quite a
trick to find a comfortable position to lie in. Think after the baby is on the outside will have no more trouble. If I do, shall consult the village osteopath.

 Malcolm sleeps alone now in your bed. Have bought a new mattress for it and he sleeps all alone in the east room. Calls it his room and seems to enjoy it.
 Am sure your dresses will be very pretty and should like to see them. Mailed the satin slippers several days ago. Hope you will reconsider having heels cut down.

You will not be wearing them every day - and only for a few hours at a time and am afraid they will not look nearly as well if altered. Did I mention death of Das
Spear's youngest child - the year old boy? about a month ago, I think
Completed

Hope they will not try to have any more now, but presume they will.

 Margaret is fine and the baby is doing well. Gains from 5 to 7 ounces each week. Received one of the Montesorri books from Helen Unterman yesterday.

Did she have the other also? seems to me there were two - a thick one & a thin one. She returned the thick one.

 Got a letter from Helen yesterday. she gave various reasons for her non appearance. Am enclosing her letter for you to read. Need not return it. it will remind

you of her former chatty
Completed

letterhead on side
M.M. Moore  Art Department                                                                      K.K. Moore  Business Mgr.
